title: Sri Lanka posts US$1.7bn current account surplus in 2025 despite trade deficit
content:
[Skip to content](https://www.newswire.lk/2026/01/30/sri-lanka-posts-us1-7bn-current-account-surplus-in-2025-despite-trade-deficit/#main)

Sri Lanka posts US$1.7bn current account surplus in 2025 despite trade deficit
==============================================================================

January 30, 2026 at 6:39 PM

[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fxzj6 "Facebook")
[](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Sri%20Lanka%20posts%20US%241.7bn%20current%20account%20surplus%20in%202025%20despite%20trade%20deficit&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fxzj6 "Twitter")
[](https://api.whatsapp.com/send?text=Sri%20Lanka%20posts%20US%241.7bn%20current%20account%20surplus%20in%202025%20despite%20trade%20deficit%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fxzj6 "Whatsapp")
[![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/newswire-icon.jpg)](https://www.newswire.lk/)

![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Untitled-design-1.jpeg)

Sri Lanka’s current account recorded a marginal surplus in December 2025, contributing to a provisional annual surplus of US$ 1.7 billion for 2025, according to the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL). Most months last year also recorded monthly current account surpluses.

Despite a record high in export earnings, the merchandise trade deficit widened, reaching around US$ 7.9 billion for 2025. Vehicle imports totaled US$ 2.05 billion, with December alone accounting for US$ 301 million. The country’s terms of trade deteriorated slightly as export prices fell faster than import prices.

The services account surplus rose to US$ 344 million in December, bringing the cumulative 2025 surplus to US$ 3.7 billion. Tourist arrivals increased 15.1% year-on-year, surpassing 2018 levels, though earnings grew marginally by 1.6%, remaining below 2018 levels.

Workers’ remittances hit a record high, exceeding US$ 8 billion in 2025, a 22.8% increase from 2024.

Foreign investments showed mixed trends, with a marginal US$ 5 million outflow from government securities in December, but a net inflow of US$ 248 million for the year. Investments in the Colombo Stock Exchange recorded a net outflow of US$ 122 million in 2025.

Gross official reserves improved to around US$ 6.8 billion by end-2025, aided by multilateral receipts and net forex purchases. The Sri Lanka rupee appreciated 0.2% against the US dollar in January 2026 following a depreciation in 2025. (NewsWire)

2026-01-30

  

Copyright © 2024. All right reserved.

 ![Light](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/plugins/wp-dark-mode/assets/images/btn-1/light.png) ![Dark](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/plugins/wp-dark-mode/assets/images/btn-1/dark.png)
summary: Sri Lanka posted a $1.7 billion current account surplus for 2025, driven by a services surplus and record remittances, despite a widening merchandise trade deficit. The article also notes improvements in foreign reserves and tourist arrivals, while highlighting mixed foreign investment flows.

Sri Lanka’s current account recorded a marginal surplus in December 2025, contributing to a provisional annual surplus of US$ 1.7Continue Reading

title: Advice Lab Unveils New 13,000+ Sqft Office, Marking Major Expansion in Financial Services BPO to Australia
content:
[Skip to content](https://www.newswire.lk/business/advice-lab-unveils-new-13000-sqft-office-marking-major-expansion-in-financial-services-bpo-to-australia/#main)

Advice Lab Unveils New 13,000+ Sqft Office, Marking Major Expansion in Financial Services BPO to Australia
==========================================================================================================

January 30, 2026 at 6:00 PM

[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fryn1 "Facebook")
[](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Advice%20Lab%20Unveils%20New%2013%2C000%2B%20Sqft%20Office%2C%20Marking%20Major%20Expansion%20in%20Financial%20Services%20BPO%20to%20Australia&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fryn1 "Twitter")
[](https://api.whatsapp.com/send?text=Advice%20Lab%20Unveils%20New%2013%2C000%2B%20Sqft%20Office%2C%20Marking%20Major%20Expansion%20in%20Financial%20Services%20BPO%20to%20Australia%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fryn1 "Whatsapp")
[![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/newswire-icon.jpg)](https://www.newswire.lk/)

![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/1.-Leadership-Team-of-Advice-Lab-with-Prad-Navaratnam-seated-middle.png)

Advice Lab, a leading provider of financial services BPO solutions to the Australian market, announced the opening of its new 13,000+ square‑foot office in Colombo, one of the most modern and dynamic workspaces in Sri Lanka. The move marks a significant milestone in the company’s rapid growth as a BPO and highlights its ongoing commitment to creating valuable job opportunities across Sri Lanka’s professional workforce.

The state‑of‑the‑art facility has been thoughtfully designed to support the company’s expanding operations and its growing portfolio of Australian financial advisers, accountants, and mortgage professionals. Purpose‑built for scale and efficiency, the workspace accommodates larger teams and advanced technology infrastructure while prioritizing employee well‑being and productivity. This emphasis on a people‑first culture is reflected in the inspiring, comfortable, and energizing environment created throughout the new office.

The facility features modern ergonomic workstations, a dedicated recreational zone, and comfortable lounge areas, complemented by a full‑service canteen operating throughout business hours. The new office is further complemented by a café offering delightful treats. With its peaceful and tranquil environment, it truly makes for an ideal place to work. Staff members also benefit from a fully equipped gym that promotes physical wellness and a healthy work‑life balance. Together, these elements highlight the company’s commitment to building a workplace where employees can thrive both personally and professionally.

“This office represents our next chapter, one defined by scale, innovation, and our unwavering commitment to our clients and our people,” said Prad Navaratnam, Managing Director. “Our new 13,000+ sqft facility gives us the space and infrastructure to grow rapidly while continuing to deliver industry‑leading financial services outsourcing to Australia. It also reflects our long‑term investment in cultivating talent and building a world‑class working environment here in Sri Lanka.”

With the relocation now complete, Advice Lab is poised for further expansion, strengthened capabilities, and continued leadership in the financial services BPO sector.

![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/2.-Recreational-area-of-Advice-Lab.jpg)

![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/3.-13000-Sqft-office.jpg)

2026-01-30

  

Copyright © 2024. All right reserved.

summary: Advice Lab has opened a new 13,000+ sqft office in Colombo to support its growing financial services BPO operations for Australian clients. The company highlights the modern workspace, employee wellness facilities, and its commitment to talent development as part of its expansion strategy.

title: 20 Local government representatives complete governance training in India
content:
[Skip to content](https://www.newswire.lk/2026/01/30/20-sri-lankan-officials-complete-governance-training-in-india/#main)

20 Local government representatives complete governance training in India
=========================================================================

January 30, 2026 at 5:47 PM

[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fauhf "Facebook")
[](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=20%20Local%20government%20representatives%20complete%20governance%20training%20in%20India&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fauhf "Twitter")
[](https://api.whatsapp.com/send?text=20%20Local%20government%20representatives%20complete%20governance%20training%20in%20India%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fauhf "Whatsapp")
[![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/newswire-icon.jpg)](https://www.newswire.lk/)

![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Photo-1-1.jpeg)

Twenty local government representatives from Sri Lanka’s upcountry region have completed a 10-day capacity-building programme at the National Institute of Rural Development and Panchayati Raj (NIRDPR) in Hyderabad, India, held from January 19 to 29, 2026.

Organized at the request of the Ceylon Workers’ Congress (CWC), the programme combined interactive sessions and field visits to expose participants to best practices in local governance, the Indian High Commission in Colombo said in a statement.

Topics included participatory planning, budgeting, women’s empowerment, health and education services, eco-tourism, and alternative livelihoods.

Delegates visited key institutions such as Anganwadi Centres, cooperative banks, women-led dairy farms, fruit and horticulture research facilities, and tea plantations in the Nilgiris.

The initiative forms part of India’s expanded capacity-building framework for Sri Lanka, announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi during his April 2025 visit. Under this framework, India now offers 700 additional customized training slots annually for Sri Lankan professionals, in addition to ongoing training under the ITEC programme and the civil service training MoU, the High Commission said. **(Newswire)**

2026-01-30

  

Copyright © 2024. All right reserved.

 ![Light](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/plugins/wp-dark-mode/assets/images/btn-1/light.png) ![Dark](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/plugins/wp-dark-mode/assets/images/btn-1/dark.png)
summary: Twenty Sri Lankan local government representatives from the upcountry region completed a 10‑day governance training program in Hyderabad, India, organized at the request of the Ceylon Workers’ Congress. The initiative is part of India’s broader capacity‑building framework for Sri Lanka, which offers additional training slots for Sri Lankan professionals.

Sri Lanka Central Bank chief warns of high yielding plantation investments
==========================================================================

By

Ranul Seneviratne

Friday January 30, 2026 5:30 pm

By Ranul Seneviratne

Friday January 30, 2026 5:30 pm

*   [](http://m.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-central-bank-chief-warns-of-high-yielding-plantation-investments-259483/)
    
*   [](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-central-bank-chief-warns-of-high-yielding-plantation-investments-259483/)
    
*   [](https://wa.me/?text=https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-central-bank-chief-warns-of-high-yielding-plantation-investments-259483/)
    

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lankans should be extra vigilant on investments in crop cultivations with higher returns as many people had ended up in such unregulated investment to find out they are also similar to illegal pyramid schemes, Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said.

In recent years, Sri Lanka has witnessed a surge in unregulated investment schemes targeting agricultural lands, often luring investors with promises of land ownership and assured monthly incomes in signed agreements.

These ventures typically market themselves as opportunities to invest in commercial farming or eco-friendly projects, offering returns that appear attractive amidst the country’s economic challenges, analysts say.

However, many of these schemes operate without proper regulatory oversight, raising concerns about their legitimacy and the protection of investors’ rights.

“They (investment agents) claim that by cultivating various crops, they can give (higher) return,” he said,

“For example, they say that by growing ni-miris (scotch bonnet pepper), you can earn a monthly interest of 30% or 40%. That means you can earn more than 120% annually. Therefore, people should realize that if such a profit can be made from an investment, they could do it themselves.”

“There is no need to give your money to someone else to do it. However, we all know that this is practically impossible to achieve.”

Weerasinghe said the Central Bank has observed an increasing trend of the public being lured toward fraudulent investment schemes in plantations and agriculture sectors.

“The first thing to remember is that plantation investments are unregulated. If you lose your money, there is no regulatory authority to handle your complaint. This is an entirely unregulated sector,” Weerasinghe warned.

He said people are being promised of deeds for the cultivation they have invested after signing contracts, citing to protect individual investments.

Currently 18 individuals or organizations are being investigated related such investments which are considered as illegal deposits, he said. (Colombo/January 30/2026)

=================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 4:46 pm

Friday January 30, 2026 4:46 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s rupee closed weaker at 309.25/35 to the US dollar in the spot market Friday, after opening at 309.10/20, having depreciated in recent weeks, while bond yields closed broadly steady, dealers said.

A bond maturing on 15.03.2028 closed at 8.95/9.05 percent.

A bond maturing on 15.09.2029 closed at 9.55/62 percent.

A bond maturing on 01.03.2030 closed flat at 9.68/72 percent.

A bond maturing on 15.03.2031 closed at 9.90/10.00 percent.

A bond maturing on 01.10.2032 closed at 10.27/30 percent.

A bond maturing on 15.06.2035 closed at 10.90/93 percent. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

Sri Lanka stocks close down, turnover pushed by capital goods, banking
======================================================================

By

Sanchitha Paranagama

Friday January 30, 2026 3:53 pm

By Sanchitha Paranagama

Friday January 30, 2026 3:53 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Colombo Stock Exchange closed down on Friday with Colombo Dockyard contributing the most to the market turnover.

The All Share Price Index dropped 0.22 percent, or 14.51 points, at 23,812.31.

S&P SL20 saw a drop of 0.13 percent, or 8.83 points, at 6,641.15.

Top positive contributors to the ASPI were Colombo Dockyard (Rs 155), Ceylon Tobacco Company (Rs 1,729.75).

Hayleys (Rs 240.75), and Richard Pieris and Company (Rs.38.10) led the negative ASPI contributions.

The market turnover was 9.19 billion rupees. A significant proportion of this was from Capital Goods (4.1 billion rupees) and Banks (2.54 billion rupees).

Colombo Dockyard was up 5.98 percent, closing at Rs.155. The company recently had a [41.73 percent stake acquired by Mazagon Dock Shipbuilders Limited](https://economynext.com/mazagon-dock-shipbuilders-acquires-41-73-pct-of-colombo-dockyard-258436/)
.

DFCC Bank said they were granted in principle approval by the Colombo Stock Exchange to [list 10 billion rupees](https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-dfcc-bank-to-list-12-pct-debentures-259462/)
 of 11.50, 11.75 and 12 percent debentures. The stock closed down 1.25 rupees at 157.

Maharaja Foods PLC announced that the proposed rights issue of shares dated January 9 was unanimously approved by shareholders at the [Extraordinary General Meeting](https://cdn.cse.lk/cmt/announcement_portal_prod/EGM%20-%20Final%20Announcement%20(2026)_43549516890501459.pdf)
 held today. The stock closed up 10 cents at 13.40 rupees. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

Sri Lanka signs deal with RPCs to increase estate sector wage
=============================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 11:53 am

Friday January 30, 2026 11:53 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Plantation and Community Infrastructure has signed an agreement with regional plantation companies (RPCs) to increase estate workers’ wages to 1,750 a day, a statement said.

A [2026 Budget proposal](https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-budget-2026-plantation-worker-wages-hiked-by-state-decree-247334/)
 was to increase by 400 rupees the current 1,350 rupee daily wage of an estate worker, with the government paying 200 of this.

This would bring the total daily wage of an estate worker to 1,750 rupees.

The revised wage is be effective from 1 January 2026.

Opposition members opposed the move as they pointed out that the government would be using public funds to pay private sector wages.

Sri Lanka RPCs are privately managed entities involved in cultivation, production, and processing of tea, rubber, coconut, and cinnamon across estates.

These include Hayleys Plantations (Kelani Valley, Talawakelle, Horana), Browns Plantations (Maturata, Udapussellawa, Hapugastenne), and Elpitiya Plantations. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

Sri Lanka’s private sector credit slows in December: CB official
================================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 11:00 am

Friday January 30, 2026 11:00 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Credit to Sri Lanka’s private sector slowed in December after being steady at around 200 billion rupees monthly, a top Central Bank official said, amid an expected slowdown in economic activities after Cyclone Ditwah disaster.

The private credit volumes from commercial banks have slowed to 183 billion rupees in December 2025 from a new high of 262 billion rupees in the previous month.

The 12-month growth in the private sector credit growth also has fallen to 25.2 percent last month, compared to 26 percent in November 2025, official data showed.

“We have seen notable expansion from June onwards by over 200 billion rupees a month, but some slow down observed in December as shown by provisional data to 183 billion,” S. Jegajeevan, Director of the Central Bank’s Economic Research Department told reporters on Wednesday (28).

She did not explain the reason for the slow down, but analysts attribute the slowdown to lower economic activities in December after the disaster late in November.

Jegajeevan said improving demand conditions as well as notable increase in vehicle imports led to strong private credit demand in the second half of 2025 with a slowdown in December. (Colombo/January 30/2026)

Sri Lanka central bank to continue dollar purchases in January
==============================================================

By

Ranul Seneviratne

Friday January 30, 2026 10:12 am

By Ranul Seneviratne

Friday January 30, 2026 10:12 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Central Bank will continue its dollar purchasing from the market in January after acquiring the US currency for the past few months straight, Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said.

The Central Bank has been buying dollars to build up foreign exchange reserves with an aim to meet targets set by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) under its 3 billion dollar External Fund Facility (EFF).

It has bought a net 2 billion US dollars in the last 12 months, official data showed.

“You can see our interventions in the market. Even if you look at the month of December, we have been intervening and purchasing a large amount of foreign exchange to build reserves up to this level,” he told reporters on Wednesday (28) after the Central Bank announced its policy rates, which were left unchanged.

“You can see that is continuing this month as well.”

The Central Bank’s dollar purchasing helped it boost foreign currency reserves to 6.8 billion dollars by end 2025. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

title: Imran Khan not the only one silenced as Pakistan military stifles dissent
content:
[Skip to content](https://www.newswire.lk/2026/01/30/imran-khan-not-the-only-one-silenced-as-pakistan-military-stifles-dissent/#main)

Imran Khan not the only one silenced as Pakistan military stifles dissent
=========================================================================

January 30, 2026 at 5:26 PM

[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2F40kf "Facebook")
[](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Imran%20Khan%20not%20the%20only%20one%20silenced%20as%20Pakistan%20military%20stifles%20dissent&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2F40kf "Twitter")
[](https://api.whatsapp.com/send?text=Imran%20Khan%20not%20the%20only%20one%20silenced%20as%20Pakistan%20military%20stifles%20dissent%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2F40kf "Whatsapp")
[![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/newswire-icon.jpg)](https://www.newswire.lk/)

![AFP via Getty Images Activists of Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party chant slogans during a protest demanding the release of jailed former Prime Minister Imran Khan, near the Adiala prison in Rawalpindi on August 5, 2025.](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/1536/cpsprodpb/a2bc/live/d16a8910-fd26-11f0-b7e1-afb6d0884c18.jpg.webp)

Pakistan’s jailed former prime minister Imran Khan hasn’t seen any visitors in more than five weeks, according to his party.

His family say this is partly to stop his words reaching the outside world. They blame the country’s military chief, Field Marshall Asim Munir, a charge the government rejects. It says the meetings stopped because Khan broke jail rules prohibiting discussion of politics.

While Khan may be silenced, he’s far from the only one under pressure.

Journalists, analysts and human rights advocates say the space to disagree with the state is increasingly limited – and the risks greater.

Last weekend, human rights lawyer Imaan Mazari and her husband were convicted of sharing anti-state social media posts.

The couple will spend 10 years in jail.

Ahead of sentencing, Amnesty International had called on Pakistan to end “coercive tactics used to silence dissent and intimidate those who defend human rights”.

![AFP via Getty Images Human rights lawyer Imaan Mazari during an interview with AFP on 20 January 2026](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/1536/cpsprodpb/ef35/live/5835a2a0-fd26-11f0-b7e1-afb6d0884c18.jpg.webp)

Khan’s family are very clear about the effort to wipe him from the public’s mind.

“There are two names you can’t have on television. You can’t say anything nice about Imran Khan, and you can’t say anything bad about Asim Munir,” his sister Aleema Khanum told the BBC. She was speaking at a recent protest by supporters a few kilometres from his cell in Rawalpindi’s Adiala jail.

It’s been more than eight weeks since Khan saw a family member, more than five since he met a lawyer and then it was only for eight minutes, his party says.  
“This is the only way we have right now to create enough pressure that we are allowed to meet him,” Khanum said at the protest. “It’s his right to meet his lawyers, it’s his right to meet his family, it’s his communication with the outside world.”

That communication from Khan has often been highly critical of Pakistan’s government and military chief. After meetings inside the jail, Khan’s words have often been posted on his X account, attributed to him and giving directions to his party and supporters.

“They are unable to block his voice because people want to hear him, they read his messages, they are not giving up on him,” Khanum says.  
But for now, with meetings stopped, so have those messages.

![Aleema Khanum at a protest in support of her brother Imran Khan the week before last](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/1536/cpsprodpb/716e/live/c30d3790-fd36-11f0-9972-d3f265c101c6.jpg.webp)

Khan, imprisoned since August 2023, is convicted in several corruption cases which he says are politically motivated.

The government and military reject claims he is being held in isolation. Talal Chaudhry, an interior minister, has called him “the most privileged prisoner in Pakistan”, with gym equipment and a cook.

After a post appeared quoting Khan on his X account, calling Munir a “mentally unstable person”, the military spokesperson held a two-hour news conference broadcast across Pakistan’s media, saying Khan had gone beyond politics and labelled him a national security threat.

“One could argue that the military is really leading the country on so many levels now that Pakistan’s coming quite close to authoritarian rule,” says Michael Kugelman, senior fellow on South Asia at the Atlantic Council.

“This is the worst the repression has been during any period of civilian rule.”

Pakistan’s military, often referred to as “the establishment”, have been an ever-present factor in the country politics, including periods of military dictatorship.

Initially, Khan and the military appeared close; many believe their backing helped bring Khan to power and the opposition at the time initially accused him of being in thrall to the military while he governed. Khan’s party denied this.

By the time he was ousted in a vote of no confidence in 2022, Khan had not only fallen out with the military leadership, but blamed them for his removal from power.

![AFP via Getty Images Policemen detain Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party supporters during a protest against the 27th constitutional amendment, in Karachi on November 21, 2025.](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/1536/cpsprodpb/b531/live/01e3c870-fd33-11f0-a8b8-bdd2c5f9bcad.png.webp)

In November 2025, a constitutional amendment granted Munir lifetime immunity from prosecution and oversight of all Pakistan’s defence forces.

Many saw it as a further sign that the military’s influence over Pakistan was at a high-water mark under a civilian government.

The current government deny the military are calling the shots.

“The civilian government is \[taking\] decisions. We are all working hand in glove,” Chaudhry says, adding the chief of defence forces “is doing a marvellous job”.  
Security sources said: “The military has always maintained it operates within legal bounds.”

But Michael Kugelman and others see a connection between the military’s involvement in politics and the amount of space to speak out.

“It’s intrinsically linked to how strong or weak a democratic government is and what their relationship is with the military,” says Munizae Jahangir, a journalist and co-chair for the Human Rights Council of Pakistan (HRCP).

“If the military is more dominant, there will be less space for protest, there will be less space for dissent, there will be less space for free expression.”

![AFP via Getty Images People walk beside a poster featuring Pakistani Army Chief General Syed Asim Munir, along a road in Muzaffarabad, the capital of Pakistan-administered Kashmir, on May 14, 2025.](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/1536/cpsprodpb/f163/live/614a8170-fd27-11f0-b7e1-afb6d0884c18.jpg.webp)

Of those already jailed, Mazari is among the most prominent. A lawyer who has worked on some of the most sensitive cases in Pakistan, she and her husband Hadi Ali Chattha were convicted of “disseminating and propagating narratives that align with hostile terrorist groups”.

The government have defended their sentencing; in response Pakistan’s information minister posted on X: “As you sow, so you shall reap!”

“Attempts to frame law-breaking as democracy or human rights are entirely misplaced,” Chaudhry said.

Other human rights advocates told the BBC they have faced limits on how they can operate.

HRCP say that their staff have been harassed on phone calls and stopped from holding round-table discussions at hotels unless they obtain permission in advance. The government says this is “to ensure security”.

Journalists, too, say they have felt pressure. In 2023, the BBC reported that TV channels had been told that they must not show Khan’s face, his voice or say his name. The topics that should not be covered, according to journalists the BBC spoke to, have expanded.

“They \[Pakistan’s authorities\] have controlled the mainstream media to a large extent,” said Azaz Syed, a reporter for Geo TV. He says that even stories tangentially linked to the military – including one he recently did on a defence housing authority – have led to phone calls from unknown numbers with warnings to go no further.

Jahangir says she has even been told by editors not to cover certain stories.

“The editors are not doing this for fun. They do fundamentally believe in freedom of expression. They are doing this in order to survive,” she says.

Journalists from other outlets who spoke to the BBC on condition of anonymity said that a culture of self-censorship was now common in newsrooms.

“There were times in the past when there was complete censorship,” one said. “Now there is self-censorship, which in many ways is worse because we are deceiving the audience.”

The BBC approached the military for comment.

Security sources told us that ISPR, the military’s communications arm, “does not regulate media content, freedom of speech, or interfere in civilian journalism, nor does it exercise any authority over public discourse beyond its lawful communication role”.

![Bloomberg via Getty Images Imran Khan, Pakistan's former prime minister, in Lahore, Pakistan, on Tuesday, Jan. 24, 2023.](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/1536/cpsprodpb/4e48/live/c4fe4c70-fd26-11f0-a8b8-bdd2c5f9bcad.jpg.webp)

Dawn newspaper – the oldest in Pakistan, founded in 1941 by the country’s founding father, Muhammad Ali Jinnah – has taken a financial hit for its reporting. In December, Dawn Media Group said it had been subject to an unannounced ban on government adverts, firstly on its newspaper, then on its TV and radio outlets, a move the Council of Newspaper Editors said was “financially crippling the organisation”.

“While some within the state may think that punishing outlets that refuse to toe the line may snuff out critical voices, in the modern age this is next to impossible,” the editorial board said.  
Information minister Atta Tarar denied that Dawn was denied government advertisement.

Several journalists said that the changes to Pakistan’s Prevention of Electronic Crimes Act in early 2025 have made the environment more difficult.

Pakistan’s authorities introduced the changes, saying they were needed to fight what the military has often termed “digital terrorism”; spreading what they see to be “anarchy and false information” to undermine the state. The country’s constitution protects the right to freedom of speech and expression subject to reasonable restrictions, security sources told the BBC.

“It’s false to claim Pakistan suppresses free speech,” says Chaudhry. He cites the dangers of social media being used for financial fraud and recruiting terrorists. “We want to regulate social media, the whole world is regulating \[it\].”

But others say they can be used to limit journalists’ ability to report.

“Changes made to the law have now made it an explicit crime to criticise the security establishment, the judiciary and definitions around national interest have been made even more vague. There are astonishingly steep fines and the penalties have been enhanced disproportionately,” says Adnan Rehmat, a media analyst based in Islamabad.

He says there are the official rules, then there are further unspoken rules: “It’s really difficult to know what the boundaries are, they are forever shifting.”

Limitations on journalists are not new in Pakistan. Under Khan’s government, journalists protested about restrictions placed on what they could publish and broadcast.

Syed sees the current situation as a continuation of the operation against the media. Jahangir also sees some level of historical continuity. “I can’t say this has been the worst time, but let’s say that times haven’t improved for us.”

While attempts to limit and intimidate critics have happened before, some think there is a new approach this time.

“It feels like something has shifted,” says Azeema Cheema, an Islamabad-based research director specialising in conflict, fragility and violence. “Because now you are using the courts. You are using institutions, not extra institutional measures.”

Those operating online outside Pakistan are in the authorities’ sights too. In early January, seven Pakistani journalists and Youtubers, including two former army officers, were tried in absentia and given life sentences for digital terrorism. The prosecution accused them of “waging war against state” and “incitement” in relation to protests that took place on 9 May 2023 after Khan’s first arrest.

In a post on X, one of the sentenced, Adil Raja, said “speaking truth to power is now called Digital Terrorism in Pakistan”.

Syed and Cheema cite this case as a particularly stark example of harsh sentencing.

“There’s been a growing realisation that the state is excessively willing and unapologetically willing to wield a blunt hammer,” says Cheema.

Where that hammer may fall next is what many we spoke to are trying to calculate. (BBC)

2026-01-30

  

Copyright © 2024. All right reserved.

summary: The article reports that jailed former Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan has been cut off from family and legal visits, allegedly as part of a broader crackdown on dissent, and highlights the recent conviction of human‑rights lawyer Imaan Mazari and her husband for sharing anti‑state posts. It frames these actions as part of a systematic effort by the military and government to silence opposition voices.

title: Apple to make foldable iPhone, Nikkei Asia reports
content:
[Skip to content](https://www.newswire.lk/2026/01/30/apple-to-make-foldable-iphone-delays-standard-model-to-2027-nikkei-asia-reports/#main)

Apple to make foldable iPhone, Nikkei Asia reports
==================================================

January 30, 2026 at 5:21 PM

[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fkaxe "Facebook")
[](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Apple%20to%20make%20foldable%20iPhone%2C%20Nikkei%20Asia%20reports&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fkaxe "Twitter")
[](https://api.whatsapp.com/send?text=Apple%20to%20make%20foldable%20iPhone%2C%20Nikkei%20Asia%20reports%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fkaxe "Whatsapp")
[![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/newswire-icon.jpg)](https://www.newswire.lk/)

![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Apple-iphone.jpg)

Apple is shifting its production focus to three high-end iPhone models for 2026, including its first-ever foldable iPhone, while delaying the launch of the standard iPhone 18 to the first half of 2027, Nikkei Asia reported Friday, citing four sources familiar with the matter.

The US tech company is expected to unveil the foldable device alongside two non-folding flagship models featuring upgraded cameras and larger displays in the second half of 2026. The decision is part of a revised marketing strategy and response to supply chain constraints, the report said.

Apple aims to optimize resource allocation and boost profitability amid rising costs for memory chips and other materials. The delay also helps reduce production risks associated with the complex manufacturing process required for its foldable device.

“Supply chain smoothness is one of the key challenges for this year, and the marketing strategy change also played a part in the decision,” an executive from an iPhone supplier told Nikkei Asia. **(Newswire)**

2026-01-30

  

Copyright © 2024. All right reserved.

 ![Light](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/plugins/wp-dark-mode/assets/images/btn-1/light.png) ![Dark](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/plugins/wp-dark-mode/assets/images/btn-1/dark.png)
summary: Apple plans to launch its first foldable iPhone in late 2026 alongside two other flagship models, while postponing the standard iPhone 18 to early 2027 to manage supply chain constraints and improve profitability. The shift reflects a revised marketing strategy and aims to allocate resources toward high‑end devices.

title: Sri Lankan arrested in Israel over alleged rape of special needs schoolgirl
content:
[Skip to content](https://www.newswire.lk/2026/01/30/sri-lankan-arrested-in-israel-over-alleged-rape-of-special-needs-schoolgirl/#main)

Sri Lankan arrested in Israel over alleged rape of special needs schoolgirl
===========================================================================

January 30, 2026 at 5:08 PM

[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2F5m5j "Facebook")
[](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Sri%20Lankan%20arrested%20in%20Israel%20over%20alleged%20rape%20of%20special%20needs%20schoolgirl&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2F5m5j "Twitter")
[](https://api.whatsapp.com/send?text=Sri%20Lankan%20arrested%20in%20Israel%20over%20alleged%20rape%20of%20special%20needs%20schoolgirl%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2F5m5j "Whatsapp")
[![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/newswire-icon.jpg)](https://www.newswire.lk/)

![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/K-web-pix-5.jpg)

A Sri Lankan national has been arrested in Israel over allegations of rape of a schoolgirl enrolled at a special needs institution, Sri Lanka’s Embassy in Israel confirmed.

The suspect, who reportedly arrived in Israel for employment in May 2025, had taken up temporary work outside his official job sector. He was arrested by police at the Beit Shemesh Police Station and remains in custody as investigations continue, according to information received by the Embassy from Interpol’s Israeli branch.

Israeli authorities are probing the case as one involving the abuse of a minor with special needs, Ambassador Nimal Bandara said.

In a statement, the Embassy reiterated Israel’s strict laws on criminal and social conduct, warning that serious offences can lead to long-term imprisonment and deportation for foreign nationals.

Sri Lankans living in Israel were urged to adhere strictly to local laws and social norms. **(Newswire)**

2026-01-30

  

Copyright © 2024. All right reserved.

summary: A Sri Lankan man was arrested in Israel on suspicion of raping a special‑needs schoolgirl, and the Sri Lankan embassy is cooperating with Israeli authorities as the investigation proceeds.

title: Wild elephant rescued from garbage pit in Digampathaha
content:
[Skip to content](https://www.newswire.lk/2026/01/30/wild-elephant-rescued-from-garbage-pit-in-digampathaha/#main)

Wild elephant rescued from garbage pit in Digampathaha
======================================================

January 30, 2026 at 4:55 PM

[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2F4730 "Facebook")
[](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Wild%20elephant%20rescued%20from%20garbage%20pit%20in%20Digampathaha&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2F4730 "Twitter")
[](https://api.whatsapp.com/send?text=Wild%20elephant%20rescued%20from%20garbage%20pit%20in%20Digampathaha%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2F4730 "Whatsapp")
[![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/newswire-icon.jpg)](https://www.newswire.lk/)

![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Elephant-trapped-Digampathana-garbage.jpg)

A wild elephant that managed to enter the Digampathaha garbage dumping site in Dambulla by breaking through an electric fence on the night of January 29, has been safely rescued after falling into a waste pit.

The incident was reported during the final stage of ongoing fence repairs, when a herd of elephants breached the site through a vulnerable section, officials said.

One elephant was found to be trapped in a large garbage disposal pit, during early morning observations today.

In response, teams from the Dambulla Municipal Council, the Fire Department, and wildlife officers quickly coordinated rescue efforts.

With support services and equipment in place, the elephant was safely freed after several hours without injury.

Officials have since reinforced the fence to prevent further intrusions. **(Newswire)**

2026-01-30

  

Copyright © 2024. All right reserved.

 ![Light](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/plugins/wp-dark-mode/assets/images/btn-1/light.png) ![Dark](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/plugins/wp-dark-mode/assets/images/btn-1/dark.png)
summary: A wild elephant entered the Digampathaha garbage dump in Dambulla, broke through an electric fence, and fell into a waste pit. Local authorities, fire services, and wildlife officers rescued the animal after several hours without injury.

title: Beijing Capital Airlines to launch flights to Sri Lanka
content:
[Skip to content](https://www.newswire.lk/2026/01/30/beijing-capital-airlines-to-launch-flights-to-sri-lanka/#main)

Beijing Capital Airlines to launch flights to Sri Lanka
=======================================================

January 30, 2026 at 4:48 PM

[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2F2108 "Facebook")
[](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Beijing%20Capital%20Airlines%20to%20launch%20flights%20to%20Sri%20Lanka&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2F2108 "Twitter")
[](https://api.whatsapp.com/send?text=Beijing%20Capital%20Airlines%20to%20launch%20flights%20to%20Sri%20Lanka%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2F2108 "Whatsapp")
[![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/newswire-icon.jpg)](https://www.newswire.lk/)

![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Beijing-Faxing-3.jpg)

Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) is set to welcome Beijing Capital Airlines as the newest addition to its airline roster, with the carrier scheduled to commence operations on January 31, 2026.

The airline will operate twice-weekly flights between Beijing Daxing International Airport and BIA, with services every Tuesday and Saturday. The new route marks a significant boost to Sri Lanka’s aviation and tourism sectors as the country enters the new year. **(Newswire)**

Sri Lanka rupee closes weaker, bond yields steady
=================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 4:46 pm

Friday January 30, 2026 4:46 pm

*   [](http://m.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-rupee-closes-weaker-bond-yields-steady-259482/)

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s rupee closed weaker at 309.25/35 to the US dollar in the spot market Friday, after opening at 309.10/20, having depreciated in recent weeks, while bond yields closed broadly steady, dealers said.

A bond maturing on 15.03.2028 closed at 8.95/9.05 percent.

A bond maturing on 15.09.2029 closed at 9.55/62 percent.

A bond maturing on 01.03.2030 closed flat at 9.68/72 percent.

A bond maturing on 15.03.2031 closed at 9.90/10.00 percent.

A bond maturing on 01.10.2032 closed at 10.27/30 percent.

A bond maturing on 15.06.2035 closed at 10.90/93 percent. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

[](https://backend.echelon.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/Echelon-Magazine-November-2025-LowRes.pdf)

[](https://backend.echelon.lk/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Echelon-Magazine-January-2026.pdf)

[](https://whatsapp.com/channel/0029VaCvssH0lwgrfqdWzO0j)

[Stocks & Companies](https://economynext.com/markets/stocks-companies/)

Sri Lanka stocks close down, turnover pushed by capital goods, banking
======================================================================

By

Sanchitha Paranagama

Friday January 30, 2026 3:53 pm

By Sanchitha Paranagama

Friday January 30, 2026 3:53 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Colombo Stock Exchange closed down on Friday with Colombo Dockyard contributing the most to the market turnover.

The All Share Price Index dropped 0.22 percent, or 14.51 points, at 23,812.31.

S&P SL20 saw a drop of 0.13 percent, or 8.83 points, at 6,641.15.

Top positive contributors to the ASPI were Colombo Dockyard (Rs 155), Ceylon Tobacco Company (Rs 1,729.75).

Hayleys (Rs 240.75), and Richard Pieris and Company (Rs.38.10) led the negative ASPI contributions.

The market turnover was 9.19 billion rupees. A significant proportion of this was from Capital Goods (4.1 billion rupees) and Banks (2.54 billion rupees).

Colombo Dockyard was up 5.98 percent, closing at Rs.155. The company recently had a [41.73 percent stake acquired by Mazagon Dock Shipbuilders Limited](https://economynext.com/mazagon-dock-shipbuilders-acquires-41-73-pct-of-colombo-dockyard-258436/)
.

DFCC Bank said they were granted in principle approval by the Colombo Stock Exchange to [list 10 billion rupees](https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-dfcc-bank-to-list-12-pct-debentures-259462/)
 of 11.50, 11.75 and 12 percent debentures. The stock closed down 1.25 rupees at 157.

Maharaja Foods PLC announced that the proposed rights issue of shares dated January 9 was unanimously approved by shareholders at the [Extraordinary General Meeting](https://cdn.cse.lk/cmt/announcement_portal_prod/EGM%20-%20Final%20Announcement%20(2026)_43549516890501459.pdf)
 held today. The stock closed up 10 cents at 13.40 rupees. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

[Continue Reading](https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-stocks-close-down-turnover-pushed-by-capital-goods-banking-259469/)

[Bonds & Forex](https://economynext.com/markets/bonds-forex/)

Sri Lanka’s DFCC Bank to list 12-pct debentures
===============================================

Friday January 30, 2026 12:49 pm

Friday January 30, 2026 12:49 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s DFCC Bank has received Colombo Stock Exchange approval to list 10 billion rupees of 11.50, 11.75 and 12 percent debentures, it said in a [stock exchange filing](https://cdn.cse.lk/cmt/announcement_portal_prod/DFCC-Circular_%20Issue%20Opening_43537987651359869.pdf)
.

DFCC Bank will issue 100 million Basel III compliant, subordinated, listed, rated, unsecured, redeemable GSS+ bonds, with a non-viability conversion option, at 100 rupees each.

The subscription list opens on February 6, and the issue is managed by Capital Alliance Partners Limited and NDB Investment Bank Limited.

The issue [was rated ‘BBB+(EXP)(lka)’](https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-dfcc-bank-green-bond-gets-bbb-rating-from-fitch-249115/)
 by Fitch Ratings. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

[Agriculture](https://economynext.com/business/agriculture/)

Sri Lanka signs deal with RPCs to increase estate sector wage
=============================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 11:53 am

Friday January 30, 2026 11:53 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Plantation and Community Infrastructure has signed an agreement with regional plantation companies (RPCs) to increase estate workers’ wages to 1,750 a day, a statement said.

A [2026 Budget proposal](https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-budget-2026-plantation-worker-wages-hiked-by-state-decree-247334/)
 was to increase by 400 rupees the current 1,350 rupee daily wage of an estate worker, with the government paying 200 of this.

This would bring the total daily wage of an estate worker to 1,750 rupees.

The revised wage is be effective from 1 January 2026.

Opposition members opposed the move as they pointed out that the government would be using public funds to pay private sector wages.

Sri Lanka RPCs are privately managed entities involved in cultivation, production, and processing of tea, rubber, coconut, and cinnamon across estates.

These include Hayleys Plantations (Kelani Valley, Talawakelle, Horana), Browns Plantations (Maturata, Udapussellawa, Hapugastenne), and Elpitiya Plantations. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

[Continue Reading](https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-signs-deal-with-rpcs-to-increase-estate-sector-wage-259450/)

[Economy](https://economynext.com/economy/)

Sri Lanka’s private sector credit slows in December: CB official
================================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 11:00 am

Friday January 30, 2026 11:00 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Credit to Sri Lanka’s private sector slowed in December after being steady at around 200 billion rupees monthly, a top Central Bank official said, amid an expected slowdown in economic activities after Cyclone Ditwah disaster.

The private credit volumes from commercial banks have slowed to 183 billion rupees in December 2025 from a new high of 262 billion rupees in the previous month.

The 12-month growth in the private sector credit growth also has fallen to 25.2 percent last month, compared to 26 percent in November 2025, official data showed.

“We have seen notable expansion from June onwards by over 200 billion rupees a month, but some slow down observed in December as shown by provisional data to 183 billion,” S. Jegajeevan, Director of the Central Bank’s Economic Research Department told reporters on Wednesday (28).

She did not explain the reason for the slow down, but analysts attribute the slowdown to lower economic activities in December after the disaster late in November.

Jegajeevan said improving demand conditions as well as notable increase in vehicle imports led to strong private credit demand in the second half of 2025 with a slowdown in December. (Colombo/January 30/2026)

[Continue Reading](https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-private-sector-credit-slows-in-december-cb-official-259401/)

[Economy](https://economynext.com/economy/)

Sri Lanka central bank to continue dollar purchases in January
==============================================================

By

Ranul Seneviratne

Friday January 30, 2026 10:12 am

By Ranul Seneviratne

Friday January 30, 2026 10:12 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Central Bank will continue its dollar purchasing from the market in January after acquiring the US currency for the past few months straight, Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said.

The Central Bank has been buying dollars to build up foreign exchange reserves with an aim to meet targets set by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) under its 3 billion dollar External Fund Facility (EFF).

It has bought a net 2 billion US dollars in the last 12 months, official data showed.

“You can see our interventions in the market. Even if you look at the month of December, we have been intervening and purchasing a large amount of foreign exchange to build reserves up to this level,” he told reporters on Wednesday (28) after the Central Bank announced its policy rates, which were left unchanged.

“You can see that is continuing this month as well.”

The Central Bank’s dollar purchasing helped it boost foreign currency reserves to 6.8 billion dollars by end 2025. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

Sri Lanka rupee opens stronger, bond yields steady
==================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 9:50 am

Friday January 30, 2026 9:50 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s rupee was quoted at 309.10/20 to the US dollar in the spot market Friday, improving from 309.58/63 the previous day, having depreciated in recent weeks, dealers said, while bond yields were broadly steady.

A bond maturing on 15.12.2029 was quoted at 9.59/64 percent, down from 9.65/70 percent.

A bond maturing on 01.03.2030 was quoted at 9.68/72 percent.

A bond maturing on 01.07.2030 was quoted at 9.70/80 percent, down from 9.75/80 percent.

A bond maturing on 15.12.2032 was quoted at 10.30/35 percent, down from 10.28/38 percent.

A bond maturing on 15.06.2034 was quoted at 10.80/90 percent.

The telegraphic transfer rates for the American dollar were 305.9500 buying, 312.9500 selling; the British pound was 420.3313 buying, and 431.8229 selling, and the euro was 362.7371 buying, 374.2851 selling.

On the Colombo Stock Exchange, the ASPI was up 0.06 percent, or 15.05 points, at 23,915; and the S&P SL20 was up 0.09 percent, or 5.92 points, at 6,649. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

title: Four arrested over fatal street racing accident in Horana
content:
[Skip to content](https://www.newswire.lk/2026/01/30/four-arrested-over-fatal-street-racing-accident-in-horana/#main)

Four arrested over fatal street racing accident in Horana
=========================================================

January 30, 2026 at 4:40 PM

[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fh9x1 "Facebook")
[](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Four%20arrested%20over%20fatal%20street%20racing%20accident%20in%20Horana&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fh9x1 "Twitter")
[](https://api.whatsapp.com/send?text=Four%20arrested%20over%20fatal%20street%20racing%20accident%20in%20Horana%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newswire.lk%2Fh9x1 "Whatsapp")
[![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/newswire-icon.jpg)](https://www.newswire.lk/)

![](https://www.newswire.lk/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Sri-Lanka-Police-1.jpg)

Four suspects have been arrested in connection with the dangerous motorcycle racing incident that occurred near the Junction on the Ratnapura–Panadura road on the night of January 16, 2026, Police said.

Horana Police apprehended the suspects on January 27 for allegedly organizing the illegal street race, assisting in its coordination, and recording the event, charging the suspects for causing a public disturbance.

The suspects, aged 19, 21, 24, and 25, are residents of Poruwadanda, Galpatha, and Karandana. They were produced before the Horana Magistrate’s Court, which ordered their remand until February 2, Police said.

Separately, on January 23, Police arrested two motorcyclists who performed one-wheeled stunts during the funeral procession for the 18-year-old who died in the street racing accident. They were also remanded until February 6.

Meanwhile, two additional suspects, both 18 years old, were arrested on January 28 for dangerously filming the motorcade while riding against traffic. They were ordered to be held until February 2.

Police have launched further investigations to trace three motorcycles used in the incident and are analyzing mobile phone data of the suspects to uncover additional evidence. **(Newswire)**

2026-01-30

summary: Four suspects have been arrested for organizing and participating in a fatal street racing incident near Horana, with additional arrests related to stunt performances during a funeral procession. Police are continuing investigations and have remanded the detainees pending court appearances.

*   [](http://m.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-stocks-close-down-turnover-pushed-by-capital-goods-banking-259469/)

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Colombo Stock Exchange closed down on Friday with Colombo Dockyard contributing the most to the market turnover.

The All Share Price Index dropped 0.22 percent, or 14.51 points, at 23,812.31.

S&P SL20 saw a drop of 0.13 percent, or 8.83 points, at 6,641.15.

Top positive contributors to the ASPI were Colombo Dockyard (Rs 155), Ceylon Tobacco Company (Rs 1,729.75).

Hayleys (Rs 240.75), and Richard Pieris and Company (Rs.38.10) led the negative ASPI contributions.

The market turnover was 9.19 billion rupees. A significant proportion of this was from Capital Goods (4.1 billion rupees) and Banks (2.54 billion rupees).

Colombo Dockyard was up 5.98 percent, closing at Rs.155. The company recently had a [41.73 percent stake acquired by Mazagon Dock Shipbuilders Limited](https://economynext.com/mazagon-dock-shipbuilders-acquires-41-73-pct-of-colombo-dockyard-258436/)
.

DFCC Bank said they were granted in principle approval by the Colombo Stock Exchange to [list 10 billion rupees](https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-dfcc-bank-to-list-12-pct-debentures-259462/)
 of 11.50, 11.75 and 12 percent debentures. The stock closed down 1.25 rupees at 157.

Maharaja Foods PLC announced that the proposed rights issue of shares dated January 9 was unanimously approved by shareholders at the [Extraordinary General Meeting](https://cdn.cse.lk/cmt/announcement_portal_prod/EGM%20-%20Final%20Announcement%20(2026)_43549516890501459.pdf)
 held today. The stock closed up 10 cents at 13.40 rupees. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Plantation and Community Infrastructure has signed an agreement with regional plantation companies (RPCs) to increase estate workers’ wages to 1,750 a day, a statement said.

A [2026 Budget proposal](https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-budget-2026-plantation-worker-wages-hiked-by-state-decree-247334/)
 was to increase by 400 rupees the current 1,350 rupee daily wage of an estate worker, with the government paying 200 of this.

This would bring the total daily wage of an estate worker to 1,750 rupees.

The revised wage is be effective from 1 January 2026.

Opposition members opposed the move as they pointed out that the government would be using public funds to pay private sector wages.

Sri Lanka RPCs are privately managed entities involved in cultivation, production, and processing of tea, rubber, coconut, and cinnamon across estates.

These include Hayleys Plantations (Kelani Valley, Talawakelle, Horana), Browns Plantations (Maturata, Udapussellawa, Hapugastenne), and Elpitiya Plantations. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

Sri Lanka’s private sector credit slows in December: CB official
================================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 11:00 am

Friday January 30, 2026 11:00 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Credit to Sri Lanka’s private sector slowed in December after being steady at around 200 billion rupees monthly, a top Central Bank official said, amid an expected slowdown in economic activities after Cyclone Ditwah disaster.

The private credit volumes from commercial banks have slowed to 183 billion rupees in December 2025 from a new high of 262 billion rupees in the previous month.

The 12-month growth in the private sector credit growth also has fallen to 25.2 percent last month, compared to 26 percent in November 2025, official data showed.

“We have seen notable expansion from June onwards by over 200 billion rupees a month, but some slow down observed in December as shown by provisional data to 183 billion,” S. Jegajeevan, Director of the Central Bank’s Economic Research Department told reporters on Wednesday (28).

She did not explain the reason for the slow down, but analysts attribute the slowdown to lower economic activities in December after the disaster late in November.

Jegajeevan said improving demand conditions as well as notable increase in vehicle imports led to strong private credit demand in the second half of 2025 with a slowdown in December. (Colombo/January 30/2026)

Sri Lanka central bank to continue dollar purchases in January
==============================================================

By

Ranul Seneviratne

Friday January 30, 2026 10:12 am

By Ranul Seneviratne

Friday January 30, 2026 10:12 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Central Bank will continue its dollar purchasing from the market in January after acquiring the US currency for the past few months straight, Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said.

The Central Bank has been buying dollars to build up foreign exchange reserves with an aim to meet targets set by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) under its 3 billion dollar External Fund Facility (EFF).

It has bought a net 2 billion US dollars in the last 12 months, official data showed.

“You can see our interventions in the market. Even if you look at the month of December, we have been intervening and purchasing a large amount of foreign exchange to build reserves up to this level,” he told reporters on Wednesday (28) after the Central Bank announced its policy rates, which were left unchanged.

“You can see that is continuing this month as well.”

The Central Bank’s dollar purchasing helped it boost foreign currency reserves to 6.8 billion dollars by end 2025. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

Sri Lanka may get over U$700mn in IMF double review
===================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 8:04 am

Friday January 30, 2026 8:04 am

ECONOMYNEXT – The International Monetary Fund is discussing combining the fifth and sixth reviews of the of the Extended Fund Facility with Sri Lanka, Mission Chief Evan Papageorgiou said after last review was delayed due to Cyclone Ditwah.

Combining reviews is a “live discussion” he told reporters in Colombo after concluding a mission to assess the impact of Cyclone Ditwah.

Sri Lanka’s President’s media office said discussions related the of “the sixth tranche under the programme would resume in March.”

Each review leads to the disbursement of 254 million special drawing rights (about 371 million dollars) at the current exchange rates making the total about 720 million US dollars if two reviews were completed together.

The staff level agreement and targets for Sri Lanka’s planned fifth review under the Extended Fund Facility in December 2025 became obsolete after spending in a budget for 2025 was increased by 500 billion rupees and economic projections became uncertain.

The fifth review was to be conducted on the fiscal and monetary targets applicable for June 2025.

However, by March 2026, December targets would be available, under the applicable program before the staff level for the fifth review.

Sri Lanka has kept most quantitative targets for June and December, emerging data show.

Sri Lanka’s reserve collections reduced after a May rate cut and insufficient deflationary policy (sell downs of central bank held domestic assets) and unsterilized over-purchases led to currency depreciation.

RELATED :

[Sri Lanka to seek central bank dollars for debt repayment if IMF tranche delayed](https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-to-seek-central-bank-dollars-for-debt-repayment-if-imf-tranche-delayed-254165/)

[Sri Lanka’s exchange rate depreciation by ‘Political Ravishment’](https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-exchange-rate-depreciation-by-political-ravishment-249531/)

However, in December cyclone Ditwah has may have reduced domestic credit, which then leads falling interest rates to a reduction in imports in the ensuing weeks helping build reserves.

Credit came to a standstill in 2004 after the tsunami struck the island.

There were also foreign inflows as Ditwah aid which can strengthen the currency if the central bank did not buy them to create new money and was allowed to hit the market. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s DFCC Bank has received Colombo Stock Exchange approval to list 10 billion rupees of 11.50, 11.75 and 12 percent debentures, it said in a [stock exchange filing](https://cdn.cse.lk/cmt/announcement_portal_prod/DFCC-Circular_%20Issue%20Opening_43537987651359869.pdf)
.

DFCC Bank will issue 100 million Basel III compliant, subordinated, listed, rated, unsecured, redeemable GSS+ bonds, with a non-viability conversion option, at 100 rupees each.

The subscription list opens on February 6, and the issue is managed by Capital Alliance Partners Limited and NDB Investment Bank Limited.

The issue [was rated ‘BBB+(EXP)(lka)’](https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-dfcc-bank-green-bond-gets-bbb-rating-from-fitch-249115/)
 by Fitch Ratings. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

Sri Lanka may get over U$700mn in IMF double review
===================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 8:04 am

Friday January 30, 2026 8:04 am

ECONOMYNEXT – The International Monetary Fund is discussing combining the fifth and sixth reviews of the of the Extended Fund Facility with Sri Lanka, Mission Chief Evan Papageorgiou said after last review was delayed due to Cyclone Ditwah.

Combining reviews is a “live discussion” he told reporters in Colombo after concluding a mission to assess the impact of Cyclone Ditwah.

Sri Lanka’s President’s media office said discussions related the of “the sixth tranche under the programme would resume in March.”

Each review leads to the disbursement of 254 million special drawing rights (about 371 million dollars) at the current exchange rates making the total about 720 million US dollars if two reviews were completed together.

The staff level agreement and targets for Sri Lanka’s planned fifth review under the Extended Fund Facility in December 2025 became obsolete after spending in a budget for 2025 was increased by 500 billion rupees and economic projections became uncertain.

The fifth review was to be conducted on the fiscal and monetary targets applicable for June 2025.

However, by March 2026, December targets would be available, under the applicable program before the staff level for the fifth review.

Sri Lanka has kept most quantitative targets for June and December, emerging data show.

Sri Lanka’s reserve collections reduced after a May rate cut and insufficient deflationary policy (sell downs of central bank held domestic assets) and unsterilized over-purchases led to currency depreciation.

[Sri Lanka’s exchange rate depreciation by ‘Political Ravishment’](https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-exchange-rate-depreciation-by-political-ravishment-249531/)

However, in December cyclone Ditwah has may have reduced domestic credit, which then leads falling interest rates to a reduction in imports in the ensuing weeks helping build reserves.

Credit came to a standstill in 2004 after the tsunami struck the island.

There were also foreign inflows as Ditwah aid which can strengthen the currency if the central bank did not buy them to create new money and was allowed to hit the market. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

Sukuk expands to new geographies, sectors; majority investment grade: Fitch Ratings
===================================================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 7:00 am

Friday January 30, 2026 7:00 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Fitch-rated sukuk showed strong resilience and credit quality in 2025, the rating agency said, with over 80 percent achieving investment grade, while simultaneously expanding into new geographies with first-time ratings in Australia, the UK, and Sri Lanka.

“First-time Fitch-rated sukuk are emerging in markets such as Australia, the UK, and Sri Lanka, despite sukuk’s additional structural complexities,” said Bashar Al Natoor, Global Head of Islamic Finance at Fitch Ratings.

“Over 80% of Fitch-rated sukuk were investment grade in 2025, with over 90% of issuers having Stable Outlooks, and no defaults over the past four years,” he added.

Sri Lanka’s first sukuk, by Vidullanka PLC, was rated ‘A+(lka)’) by Fitch.

The full statement is reproduced below:

**Sukuk Expands to New Geographies, Sectors; Majority Investment Grade**

Fitch-rated sukuk are resilient, underpinned by robust credit quality, record issuance, and expansion across new regions and sectors.

“First-time Fitch-rated sukuk are emerging in markets such as Australia, the UK, and Sri Lanka, despite sukuk’s additional structural complexities,” said Bashar Al Natoor, Global Head of Islamic Finance at Fitch Ratings. “Over 80% of Fitch-rated sukuk were investment grade in 2025, with over 90% of issuers having Stable Outlooks, and no defaults over the past four years,” he added.

Coverage remains concentrated in the Middle East and Asia. The vast majority of rated sukuk are senior unsecured, but a rising share are subordinated, adding to the industry’s maturity. Maturity profiles skew towards medium-term sukuk.

Fitch rated Australia’s first sharia-compliant notes (Macquarie Group Limited, ‘A’), the UK’s first public sharia-compliant RMBS from a non-bank lender (Meridian Funding 2025-1 plc), and Sri Lanka’s first sukuk (Vidullanka PLC, ‘A+(lka)’). Fitch also rated the largest sukuk from Africa, issued by Egypt (‘B’), Turkiye’s first corporate sukuk (Turk Telekom), and first sukuk with payment-in-kind features. State investment funds also issued sukuk including the UAE’s Mubadala, Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund and the Turkiye Wealth Fund. Fitch rates over 73% of outstanding US dollar sukuk, with vast majority denominated in dollars.

Fitch-rated sukuk outstanding rose 23% yoy to USD240 billion at end-2025, as global issuance surpassed USD300 billion – a 25% increase to record levels. Fitch expects issuance to slow during Ramadan in 1Q26. Most sukuk (39%) were rated in the ‘A’ category, followed by ‘BBB’ (26.2%) and ‘BB’ (10.5%). Fitch upgraded Oman to ‘BBB-’ and Pakistan to ‘B-’ in 2025, with related sukuk upgrades.

Most sukuk are asset-based, but asset-backed supply is growing, notably from supranational and UK issuers. Structures are predominantly bullet and fixed-rate, and about 12% are ESG sukuk. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

Sri Lanka signs deal with RPCs to increase estate sector wage
=============================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 11:53 am

Friday January 30, 2026 11:53 am

*   [](http://m.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-signs-deal-with-rpcs-to-increase-estate-sector-wage-259450/)

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Plantation and Community Infrastructure has signed an agreement with regional plantation companies (RPCs) to increase estate workers’ wages to 1,750 a day, a statement said.

A [2026 Budget proposal](https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-budget-2026-plantation-worker-wages-hiked-by-state-decree-247334/)
 was to increase by 400 rupees the current 1,350 rupee daily wage of an estate worker, with the government paying 200 of this.

This would bring the total daily wage of an estate worker to 1,750 rupees.

The revised wage is be effective from 1 January 2026.

Opposition members opposed the move as they pointed out that the government would be using public funds to pay private sector wages.

Sri Lanka RPCs are privately managed entities involved in cultivation, production, and processing of tea, rubber, coconut, and cinnamon across estates.

These include Hayleys Plantations (Kelani Valley, Talawakelle, Horana), Browns Plantations (Maturata, Udapussellawa, Hapugastenne), and Elpitiya Plantations. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

Sri Lanka’s private sector credit slows in December: CB official
================================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 11:00 am

Friday January 30, 2026 11:00 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Credit to Sri Lanka’s private sector slowed in December after being steady at around 200 billion rupees monthly, a top Central Bank official said, amid an expected slowdown in economic activities after Cyclone Ditwah disaster.

The private credit volumes from commercial banks have slowed to 183 billion rupees in December 2025 from a new high of 262 billion rupees in the previous month.

The 12-month growth in the private sector credit growth also has fallen to 25.2 percent last month, compared to 26 percent in November 2025, official data showed.

“We have seen notable expansion from June onwards by over 200 billion rupees a month, but some slow down observed in December as shown by provisional data to 183 billion,” S. Jegajeevan, Director of the Central Bank’s Economic Research Department told reporters on Wednesday (28).

She did not explain the reason for the slow down, but analysts attribute the slowdown to lower economic activities in December after the disaster late in November.

Jegajeevan said improving demand conditions as well as notable increase in vehicle imports led to strong private credit demand in the second half of 2025 with a slowdown in December. (Colombo/January 30/2026)

Sri Lanka central bank to continue dollar purchases in January
==============================================================

By

Ranul Seneviratne

Friday January 30, 2026 10:12 am

By Ranul Seneviratne

Friday January 30, 2026 10:12 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Central Bank will continue its dollar purchasing from the market in January after acquiring the US currency for the past few months straight, Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said.

The Central Bank has been buying dollars to build up foreign exchange reserves with an aim to meet targets set by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) under its 3 billion dollar External Fund Facility (EFF).

It has bought a net 2 billion US dollars in the last 12 months, official data showed.

“You can see our interventions in the market. Even if you look at the month of December, we have been intervening and purchasing a large amount of foreign exchange to build reserves up to this level,” he told reporters on Wednesday (28) after the Central Bank announced its policy rates, which were left unchanged.

“You can see that is continuing this month as well.”

The Central Bank’s dollar purchasing helped it boost foreign currency reserves to 6.8 billion dollars by end 2025. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

However, in December cyclone Ditwah has may have reduced domestic credit, which then leads falling interest rates to a reduction in imports in the ensuing weeks helping build reserves.

Credit came to a standstill in 2004 after the tsunami struck the island.

There were also foreign inflows as Ditwah aid which can strengthen the currency if the central bank did not buy them to create new money and was allowed to hit the market. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

Sukuk expands to new geographies, sectors; majority investment grade: Fitch Ratings
===================================================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 7:00 am

Friday January 30, 2026 7:00 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Fitch-rated sukuk showed strong resilience and credit quality in 2025, the rating agency said, with over 80 percent achieving investment grade, while simultaneously expanding into new geographies with first-time ratings in Australia, the UK, and Sri Lanka.

“First-time Fitch-rated sukuk are emerging in markets such as Australia, the UK, and Sri Lanka, despite sukuk’s additional structural complexities,” said Bashar Al Natoor, Global Head of Islamic Finance at Fitch Ratings.

“Over 80% of Fitch-rated sukuk were investment grade in 2025, with over 90% of issuers having Stable Outlooks, and no defaults over the past four years,” he added.

Sri Lanka’s first sukuk, by Vidullanka PLC, was rated ‘A+(lka)’) by Fitch.

The full statement is reproduced below:

**Sukuk Expands to New Geographies, Sectors; Majority Investment Grade**

Fitch-rated sukuk are resilient, underpinned by robust credit quality, record issuance, and expansion across new regions and sectors.

“First-time Fitch-rated sukuk are emerging in markets such as Australia, the UK, and Sri Lanka, despite sukuk’s additional structural complexities,” said Bashar Al Natoor, Global Head of Islamic Finance at Fitch Ratings. “Over 80% of Fitch-rated sukuk were investment grade in 2025, with over 90% of issuers having Stable Outlooks, and no defaults over the past four years,” he added.

Coverage remains concentrated in the Middle East and Asia. The vast majority of rated sukuk are senior unsecured, but a rising share are subordinated, adding to the industry’s maturity. Maturity profiles skew towards medium-term sukuk.

Fitch rated Australia’s first sharia-compliant notes (Macquarie Group Limited, ‘A’), the UK’s first public sharia-compliant RMBS from a non-bank lender (Meridian Funding 2025-1 plc), and Sri Lanka’s first sukuk (Vidullanka PLC, ‘A+(lka)’). Fitch also rated the largest sukuk from Africa, issued by Egypt (‘B’), Turkiye’s first corporate sukuk (Turk Telekom), and first sukuk with payment-in-kind features. State investment funds also issued sukuk including the UAE’s Mubadala, Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund and the Turkiye Wealth Fund. Fitch rates over 73% of outstanding US dollar sukuk, with vast majority denominated in dollars.

Fitch-rated sukuk outstanding rose 23% yoy to USD240 billion at end-2025, as global issuance surpassed USD300 billion – a 25% increase to record levels. Fitch expects issuance to slow during Ramadan in 1Q26. Most sukuk (39%) were rated in the ‘A’ category, followed by ‘BBB’ (26.2%) and ‘BB’ (10.5%). Fitch upgraded Oman to ‘BBB-’ and Pakistan to ‘B-’ in 2025, with related sukuk upgrades.

Most sukuk are asset-based, but asset-backed supply is growing, notably from supranational and UK issuers. Structures are predominantly bullet and fixed-rate, and about 12% are ESG sukuk. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

Sri Lanka’s private sector credit slows in December: CB official
================================================================

Friday January 30, 2026 11:00 am

Friday January 30, 2026 11:00 am

*   [](http://m.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-private-sector-credit-slows-in-december-cb-official-259401/)
    
*   [](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-private-sector-credit-slows-in-december-cb-official-259401/)
    
*   [](https://wa.me/?text=https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-private-sector-credit-slows-in-december-cb-official-259401/)
    

ECONOMYNEXT – Credit to Sri Lanka’s private sector slowed in December after being steady at around 200 billion rupees monthly, a top Central Bank official said, amid an expected slowdown in economic activities after Cyclone Ditwah disaster.

The private credit volumes from commercial banks have slowed to 183 billion rupees in December 2025 from a new high of 262 billion rupees in the previous month.

The 12-month growth in the private sector credit growth also has fallen to 25.2 percent last month, compared to 26 percent in November 2025, official data showed.

“We have seen notable expansion from June onwards by over 200 billion rupees a month, but some slow down observed in December as shown by provisional data to 183 billion,” S. Jegajeevan, Director of the Central Bank’s Economic Research Department told reporters on Wednesday (28).

She did not explain the reason for the slow down, but analysts attribute the slowdown to lower economic activities in December after the disaster late in November.

Jegajeevan said improving demand conditions as well as notable increase in vehicle imports led to strong private credit demand in the second half of 2025 with a slowdown in December. (Colombo/January 30/2026)

Sri Lanka central bank to continue dollar purchases in January
==============================================================

By

Ranul Seneviratne

Friday January 30, 2026 10:12 am

By Ranul Seneviratne

Friday January 30, 2026 10:12 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Central Bank will continue its dollar purchasing from the market in January after acquiring the US currency for the past few months straight, Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said.

The Central Bank has been buying dollars to build up foreign exchange reserves with an aim to meet targets set by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) under its 3 billion dollar External Fund Facility (EFF).

It has bought a net 2 billion US dollars in the last 12 months, official data showed.

“You can see our interventions in the market. Even if you look at the month of December, we have been intervening and purchasing a large amount of foreign exchange to build reserves up to this level,” he told reporters on Wednesday (28) after the Central Bank announced its policy rates, which were left unchanged.

“You can see that is continuing this month as well.”

The Central Bank’s dollar purchasing helped it boost foreign currency reserves to 6.8 billion dollars by end 2025. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s rupee was quoted at 309.10/20 to the US dollar in the spot market Friday, improving from 309.58/63 the previous day, having depreciated in recent weeks, dealers said, while bond yields were broadly steady.

A bond maturing on 15.12.2029 was quoted at 9.59/64 percent, down from 9.65/70 percent.

A bond maturing on 01.03.2030 was quoted at 9.68/72 percent.

A bond maturing on 01.07.2030 was quoted at 9.70/80 percent, down from 9.75/80 percent.

A bond maturing on 15.12.2032 was quoted at 10.30/35 percent, down from 10.28/38 percent.

A bond maturing on 15.06.2034 was quoted at 10.80/90 percent.

The telegraphic transfer rates for the American dollar were 305.9500 buying, 312.9500 selling; the British pound was 420.3313 buying, and 431.8229 selling, and the euro was 362.7371 buying, 374.2851 selling.

On the Colombo Stock Exchange, the ASPI was up 0.06 percent, or 15.05 points, at 23,915; and the S&P SL20 was up 0.09 percent, or 5.92 points, at 6,649. (Colombo/Jan30/2026)
