Sri Lanka stocks close down, real estate shares push turnover
=============================================================

By

Sanchitha Paranagama

Thursday January 29, 2026 4:11 pm

By Sanchitha Paranagama

Thursday January 29, 2026 4:11 pm

*   [](http://m.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-stocks-close-down-real-estate-shares-push-turnover-259361/)
    
*   [](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-stocks-close-down-real-estate-shares-push-turnover-259361/)
    
*   [](https://wa.me/?text=https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-stocks-close-down-real-estate-shares-push-turnover-259361/)
    

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Colombo Stock Exchange saw a dip on Thursday as some companies saw some selling pressure despite overall buying interest, brokers said.

The All Share Price Index dropped 0.38 percent, or 91.22 points, to close at 23,900.89.

S&P SL20 saw a marginal drop of 0.22 percent, or 14.55 points, closing at 6,655.66.

“There was some volatility despite buying interest in the overall market,” Dimantha Matthew Chief Research and Strategy Officer at First Capital Holdings PLC, said.

“We are seeing speculative stocks, like Dockyard, coming down in price. Even John Keells Holdings, despite its good results, saw some selling pressure in the day.”

Top negative contributors to the ASPI were Senkadagala Finance (Rs.1,005), Ceylon Tobacco Company (Rs.1,701.50), John Keells Holdings (Rs.22.70).

The market turnover was 6.92 billion rupees. A significant proportion of this was from Capital Goods (1.55 billion rupees) and Real Estate Management and Development (1.37 billion rupees).

“There is investor interest into the real estate sector stocks,” Matthew said.

Prime Lands Residencies contributed 1.2 billion rupees in turnover; the stock gained 5.88 percent to close at 46.80 rupees.

Meanwhile, Senkadagala Finance saw a restructuring of their board of directors, and the appointment of Keshav Balasuriya as Chief Executive Officer. The stock closed down 83.75 rupees at 1,005. (Colombo/Jan29/2026)

Sri Lanka’s Altair issues title deeds under Blackstone management
=================================================================

Thursday January 29, 2026 2:05 pm

Thursday January 29, 2026 2:05 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Altair Residences, a high rise project in Colombo, has begun issuing title deeds, after being taken over by Blackstone India, a statement said.

The high rise project promoted by Indocean Developers Pvt Ltd (IDPL), was mired in legal disputes before the Blackstone take-over.

Over 100 individual title deeds were executed by apartment owners, providing owners with legal title to their apartments.

The process will be speeded in the future, the statement said.

“Over the past six months, this process at Altair has moved forward in a structured and transparent manner, alongside the formal establishment of owner-led governance,” said Thilan Wijesinghe, Chairman of TWC Holdings, who, together with a team from TWC, represents Blackstone’s interests in Sri Lanka.

Altair’s Management Council has been constituted, and the council appointed Realty Management Services (RMS), a subsidiary of Overseas Realty Ceylon PLC, as the new facility manager of Altair.

“The appointment of experienced facility managers are fundamental building block for long-term value-creation for apartment owners and proper asset stewardship,” Wijesinghe said. (Colombo/Jan29/2026)

Sri Lanka’s hotel bookings dip in December: Chamber chief
=========================================================

By

Ranul Seneviratne

Thursday January 29, 2026 1:13 pm

By Ranul Seneviratne

Thursday January 29, 2026 1:13 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Hotel reservations by tourists in Sri Lanka have dipped in December, after Cyclone Ditwah devastation in November despite hotel damage being minimal, Krishan Balendra, Chairman of the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce said.

“For tourism, I feel that in December, there would have been a 5 percent to 10 percent impact on booking,” Balendra told an economic forum on Wednesday organized by Asia Securities.

In late 2025, Cyclone Ditwah delivered a sharp but localized blow to Sri Lanka’s tourism sector, striking at the onset of the peak travel season.

“In tourism, there were two aspects: the impact on bookings and infrastructure damage,” Balendra said.

“Tourist hotels association collected information from member companies and found the total damage was about 500 million rupees, again, not a material number at all.”

The disaster caused damage to infrastructure in the central highlands, leading to the temporary closure of iconic UNESCO World Heritage sites like Horton Plains and causing an estimated 18-month disruption to the world-famous Kandy-Ella railway line.

While nature-based tourism in the hill country faced the brunt of the storm, major coastal hubs and the Cultural Triangle remained largely operational.

Despite an estimated 4.1 billion dollars in total national damage, the tourism industry has shown resilience; the sector recorded a 9.7 percent growth in arrivals in early 2026 compared to the previous year. (Colombo/Jan29/2026 – Corrected – hotel reservation dip in December, not January)

Sri Lanka’s WindForce ‘A+(lka)’ rating affirmed by Fitch
========================================================

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:57 am

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:57 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Fitch Ratings has affirmed Sri Lanka-based power generator WindForce’s National Long-Term Rating at ‘A+'(lka), with a stable outlook, based on its growing scale as a prominent renewable power generator in the island and several regional markets.

“WindForce’s rating reflects its growing scale as a prominent renewable power generator in Sri Lanka and several regional markets, its resource diversity and contractual cashflows via long-term power purchase agreements (PPAs),” Fitch Ratings said.

However, the rating agency [pointed out](https://www.fitchratings.com/research/corporate-finance/fitch-affirms-sri-lanka-windforce-at-a-lka-outlook-stable-26-01-2026)
 that WindForce’s rating is constrained by the credit profile of CEB, the sole electricity transmitter and distributor in Sri Lanka.

The Fitch statement is reproduced below:

**Fitch Affirms Sri Lanka’s WindForce at ‘A+(lka)’; Outlook Stable**

Fitch Ratings has affirmed Sri Lanka-based power generator WindForce PLC’s National Long-Term Rating at ‘A+'(lka). The Outlook is Stable.

WindForce’s rating reflects its growing scale as a prominent renewable power generator in Sri Lanka and several regional markets, its resource diversity and contractual cashflows via long-term power purchase agreements (PPAs). WindForce’s rating is constrained by the credit profile of Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB, A(lka)/Stable), which is a key off-taker accounting for over 80% of WindForce’s EBIT.

Fitch forecasts WindForce’s EBITDA net leverage to rise in the financial year ending March 2027 (FY27) on high debt-funded capex for new generation plants and reduce thereafter as the new plants are commissioned, driving the Stable Outlook. However, inability to deleverage in FY28 in line with our expectations could pressure WindForce’s rating.

**Key Rating Drivers**

**Temporarily High Leverage on Capex:** WindForce expects capex of over LKR40 billion for solar and wind power plants in the next two years with most outflows in FY27. This includes a 100MW solar plant with integrated battery storage, which is Sri Lanka’s largest renewable energy project, under a joint venture with Lakdhanavi Ltd (AA-(lka)/Stable). Fitch estimates WindForce’s generation capacity to rise to over 200MW by FY28 as a result.

EBITDA net leverage will rise to around 6.8x in FY27, before moderating to around 4.6x by FY28 as the plants are commissioned. Execution risks for these projects are low, supported by the company’s record in similar projects, the limited construction complexity of solar and wind projects, the requisite regulatory approvals and offtake agreements in place, with transmission lines constructed or right-of-way established. Additionally, the plants’ long-term PPAs with CEB are in place at preset tariffs, mitigating demand risk.

**Counterparty Constrains Rating:** WindForce’s rating is constrained by the credit profile of CEB, the sole electricity transmitter and distributor in Sri Lanka, despite CEB’s improved financial performance. CEB’s rating depends on support from the Sri Lankan sovereign (Long-Term Local-Currency Issuer Default Rating (IDR): CCC+; Long-Term Foreign-Currency IDR: CCC+).. WindForce derived around 70% of its EBIT from CEB in FY23-FY25, with the share rising to around 80% in FY25 after the commissioning of the Kebitigollewa solar project. We expect WindForce’s cash flow exposure to CEB to increase in FY26-FY29 once new projects are commissioned.

**Risks to Cost-Reflective Tariffs:** Fitch sees risks to CEB’s implementation of cost-reflective tariffs, which could weigh on its balance sheet and pressure settlements to domestic power producers. This is due to the government’s competing priorities of managing inflation, CEB’s financial health, and the state’s own finances. CEB’s EBIT turned negative in 1Q25 due to costs rising faster than approved tariff increases. However, tariff revisions since have improved CEB’s EBIT to breakeven levels in 9M25. WindForce’s average receivable days are steady at around 40 as of 30 September 2025, compared to the peak of around 350 days in FY23.

**Steady EBITDA Margin:** We expect EBITDA margins to improve from around 65% in FY25 to around 70% in FY26-FY28. This reflects operating expenses normalising following increased repairs and maintenance at wind plants, which were deferred from previous years. WindForce’s PPAs offer long-term cash flow visibility, with a weighted-average remaining contract life of over 10 years, but generation volume can be affected by seasonal and climatic patterns. This is mitigated by its diversified portfolio, comprising wind (74MW), solar (55MW) and hydro (15MW) , totaling 145MW, on an alternating current equivalent basis (AC), across 23 power plants excluding associates and joint ventures.

**Peer Analysis**

WindForce is rated one notch below domestic power producer and engineering, procurement and construction contractor Lakdhanavi. The difference is on account of Lakdhanavi’s larger operating scale as a critical base-load power generator in Sri Lanka as well as its higher geographic and business diversification.

Both Lakdhanavi and WindForce have significant exposure to CEB. However, Lakdhanavi also has operations and maintenance (O&M) services, manufactures transformers and switchgears, and offers galvanising services, which provides a degree of diversification. We also believe CEB is likely to prioritise payments to Lakdhanavi even in situations where its own financial profile is stretched, given Lakdhanavi provides O&M services to one of Sri Lanka’s largest power plants, and is investing in a large liquefied natural gas power plant, all of which are critical to Sri Lanka’s power generation and to CEB’s future strategy.

Resus Energy PLC (A-(lka)/Stable), a domestic power producer, is rated two notches below WindForce. Resus also benefits from contractual revenue visibility via its PPAs with CEB. However, Resus’ lower rating reflects its tighter liquidity than WindForce and smaller operating scale with narrower access to domestic banks.

Vidullanka PLC (A+(lka)/Stable) is rated at the same level as WindForce. WindForce has larger operating capacity than Vidullanka and more diversified power generation resources. This is counterbalanced by Vidullanka’s exposure to the state-owned utility of Uganda (B/Stable) and concentration in hydropower generation. Most of Vidullanka’s cash flow stems from overseas, while most of its debt is onshore with Sri Lankan banks, exposing the company to potential repatriation risks. However, Vidullanka’s track record of overseas receipts has been steady.

**Fitch’s Key Rating-Case Assumptions**

Revenue to remain flat in FY26 then increase by over 30% annually in FY27 and FY28 from new projects

EBITDA margin of around 70% in FY26 and FY27;

Receivable days steady at around 40

Capex of around LKR15 billion in FY26 and around LKR30 billion in FY27

Dividend payout of 80% of prior year profit.

**RATING SENSITIVITIES**

**Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Negative Rating Action/Downgrade**  
EBITDA net leverage above 5.0x for a sustained period;  
EBITDA interest coverage below 1.5x for a sustained period.

**Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Positive Rating Action/Upgrade**  
A sustained and substantial reduction in counterparty risk, as reflected in a continued improvement in CEB’s credit profile.

**Liquidity and Debt Structure**

WindForce’s liquidity is subject to timely collection of dues from CEB. The company reported over LKR1.3 billion of readily available cash as of 30 September 2025 and had access to around LKR7 billion in unutilised, albeit uncommitted, credit lines from local banks against LKR1.4 billion of debt maturing in the next 12 months. Maturing debt mainly comprises the current portion of long-term debt obtained to fund the investments in its power plants.

We expect the company to generate negative FCF in the near-to-medium term due to high capex. However, WindForce has adequate access to domestic banks, as most banks are willing to provide longer-tenured facilities for the company’s operating power plants that have more than 10 years remaining under their PPAs.

**Issuer Profile**

WindForce is a leading renewable power producer in Sri Lanka with a total installed power generation capacity of around 145MW (excluding associates and joint ventures) as of 31 March 2025. Most of the installed capacity is in Sri Lanka (132MW), with the rest in Uganda (13MW). The company is listed on the Colombo Stock Exchange.

**REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING**  
The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

Sri Lanka offers grants, low interest loans for businesses hit by Cyclone Ditwah
================================================================================

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:13 am

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:13 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is offering grants of 25,000 to 200,000 rupees for micro and small enterprises affected by Cyclone Ditwah, up to 5 million rupees for commercial building repairs, and 3-5 percent interest loans with 10-year repayment options.

The president’s media division set out the ‘relief package’ as follows:

**New Circular Issued to Support Disaster-Affected Micro, Small and Self-Employed Businesses**

– Financial assistance of Rs. 200,000 for micro, small and self-employed businesses registered with the Ministry of Industry  
– Financial assistance of Rs. 200,000 for micro, small and self-employed businesses registered as businesses at Divisional Secretariat offices  
– Financial assistance of Rs. 50,000 for unregistered home-based businesses operating from permanent structures  
– Rs. 50,000 Compensation Allocated for Unregistered Production Industries and Greenhouses  
– Temporary Pedestrian and Mobile Business establishments to Receive Rs. 25,000 Compensation

A new circular has been issued by the Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development to provide relief to micro, small and self-employed businesses affected by the emergency situation caused by Cyclone Ditwah. The circular has been issued in line with Circular No. 08/2025, which was introduced to restore disrupted livelihoods following the disaster.

The Government programme to empower communities affected by the disaster was introduced through Budget Circular No. 08/2025 dated December 5, 2025. Expanding this relief framework further and ensuring more effective and efficient delivery of assistance, additional circulars No. 08/2025(i) dated December 20, 2025 and No. 08/2025(iii) dated January 22, 2026 have been issued.

The social empowerment programme under the newly issued circular is structured as follows.

Assistance for affected individual, small and micro businesses

A one-time grant to restore businesses damaged by the disaster to a condition suitable for reopening.

LKR 200,000 for individual, small and micro-businesses registered with the Ministry of Industry.

LKR 200,000 for individual, small and micro-businesses registered with the Divisional Secretariat as a business entity.

LKR 50,000 for unregistered home-based businesses operated from a permanent structure.

LKR 50,000 per unit for unregistered production industries, including greenhouses.

LKR 25,000 for temporary business setups, including mobile and street hawking.

A grant will be provided to owners of the commercial buildings affected by the disaster to restore their business premises to operational condition.

A grant of Rs. 500,000/- will be provided to each business building owner who voluntarily opts to receive assistance without a damage assessment.

A grant of up to Rs. 5,000,000/- will be provided to each business building owner who opts to receive assistance after a damage assessment, based on the assessed value of the building.

In addition to the above grants, the following loan facilities have also been provided.

In addition to these grants, the Treasury has introduced a new credit scheme to provide loans for business owners whose enterprises were affected by the disaster, enabling them to restart their operations and meet essential requirements.

Accordingly:

Facilities have been provided for affected businesses to obtain loans ranging from Rs. 250,000 to Rs. 25,000,000 through the banking system at an interest rate of 3%, with a 6-month grace period and repayment over 3 years to restart their operations.

As part of the investment loans for business reconstruction, entrepreneurs whose businesses were damaged can access bank loans of up to Rs. 25 million at an interest rate of 5%, with a 12-month grace period and repayment over 10 years. (Colombo/Jan29/2026)

Sri Lanka’s HNB to offer home loans for Baili Investments’ Silk Rajagiriya
==========================================================================

HNB’s Head of Retail Banking/Senior VP Kanchana Karunagama, exchanges the agreement with Director of Baili Investments, Xueyuan Deng, with representatives of the two organizations.

Thursday January 29, 2026 10:09 am

Thursday January 29, 2026 10:09 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Hatton National Bank is partnering with Baili Investments Lanka (Pvt) Ltd to provide home loans for Silk Rajagiriya, a residential complex being built with recreational facilities.

The development comprises 6 high-rise towers with a shopping complex, cinema, clubhouse, indoor golf, art gallery, rooftop leisure areas, swimming pool, and jogging track.

“Silk Rajagiriya replicates modern living, and we are proud to support the community in accessing this opportunity with confidence,” HNB’s Head of Retail Banking/ Senior Vice President, Kanchana Karunagama, said.

The agreement is valid until 31 December 2026.

Silk Rajagiriya is located at the junction of Buthgamuwa Road and Parliament Road. Construction is currently at the eighth floor with completion projected for September 2028.

Baili Investments is a BOI-registered developer with backing from Hong Kong investors.

“Partnering with HNB ensures home financing is straightforward, strengthens confidence in the real estate sector, and reinforces our commitment to delivering a premium living experience,” Xueyuan Deng, Director of Baili Investments said. (Colombo/Jan29/2026)

Thursday January 29, 2026 3:40 pm

Thursday January 29, 2026 3:40 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka has sold 12,500 million rupees of treasury bills offered on tap at average rates of 7.84 percent, 8.26 percent and 8.36 percent, the public debt management office said, bringing the total of bills sold this week to 137.5 billion rupees.

The debt office sold 3-month bills at 7.84 percent.

The debt office sold 6-month bills at 8.26 percent.

The debt office sold 12-month bills at 8.36 percent.

Total market subscription was 54,162 million rupees.

On Wednesday (28) the debt office raised 125 billion rupees of 3, 6 and 12 month bills.

**Read more**  
[Sri Lanka Treasury bill yields drop across yields](https://economynext.com/sri-lanka-treasury-bill-yields-drop-across-yields-259241/)

The date of settlement is January 30. (Colombo/Jan29/2026)

Sri Lanka’s Altair issues title deeds under Blackstone management
=================================================================

Thursday January 29, 2026 2:05 pm

Thursday January 29, 2026 2:05 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Altair Residences, a high rise project in Colombo, has begun issuing title deeds, after being taken over by Blackstone India, a statement said.

The high rise project promoted by Indocean Developers Pvt Ltd (IDPL), was mired in legal disputes before the Blackstone take-over.

Over 100 individual title deeds were executed by apartment owners, providing owners with legal title to their apartments.

The process will be speeded in the future, the statement said.

“Over the past six months, this process at Altair has moved forward in a structured and transparent manner, alongside the formal establishment of owner-led governance,” said Thilan Wijesinghe, Chairman of TWC Holdings, who, together with a team from TWC, represents Blackstone’s interests in Sri Lanka.

Altair’s Management Council has been constituted, and the council appointed Realty Management Services (RMS), a subsidiary of Overseas Realty Ceylon PLC, as the new facility manager of Altair.

“The appointment of experienced facility managers are fundamental building block for long-term value-creation for apartment owners and proper asset stewardship,” Wijesinghe said. (Colombo/Jan29/2026)

=========================================================

By

Ranul Seneviratne

Thursday January 29, 2026 1:13 pm

By Ranul Seneviratne

Thursday January 29, 2026 1:13 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Hotel reservations by tourists in Sri Lanka have dipped in December, after Cyclone Ditwah devastation in November despite hotel damage being minimal, Krishan Balendra, Chairman of the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce said.

“For tourism, I feel that in December, there would have been a 5 percent to 10 percent impact on booking,” Balendra told an economic forum on Wednesday organized by Asia Securities.

In late 2025, Cyclone Ditwah delivered a sharp but localized blow to Sri Lanka’s tourism sector, striking at the onset of the peak travel season.

“In tourism, there were two aspects: the impact on bookings and infrastructure damage,” Balendra said.

“Tourist hotels association collected information from member companies and found the total damage was about 500 million rupees, again, not a material number at all.”

The disaster caused damage to infrastructure in the central highlands, leading to the temporary closure of iconic UNESCO World Heritage sites like Horton Plains and causing an estimated 18-month disruption to the world-famous Kandy-Ella railway line.

While nature-based tourism in the hill country faced the brunt of the storm, major coastal hubs and the Cultural Triangle remained largely operational.

Despite an estimated 4.1 billion dollars in total national damage, the tourism industry has shown resilience; the sector recorded a 9.7 percent growth in arrivals in early 2026 compared to the previous year. (Colombo/Jan29/2026 – Corrected – hotel reservation dip in December, not January)

Sri Lanka’s WindForce ‘A+(lka)’ rating affirmed by Fitch
========================================================

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:57 am

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:57 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Fitch Ratings has affirmed Sri Lanka-based power generator WindForce’s National Long-Term Rating at ‘A+'(lka), with a stable outlook, based on its growing scale as a prominent renewable power generator in the island and several regional markets.

“WindForce’s rating reflects its growing scale as a prominent renewable power generator in Sri Lanka and several regional markets, its resource diversity and contractual cashflows via long-term power purchase agreements (PPAs),” Fitch Ratings said.

However, the rating agency [pointed out](https://www.fitchratings.com/research/corporate-finance/fitch-affirms-sri-lanka-windforce-at-a-lka-outlook-stable-26-01-2026)
 that WindForce’s rating is constrained by the credit profile of CEB, the sole electricity transmitter and distributor in Sri Lanka.

The Fitch statement is reproduced below:

**Fitch Affirms Sri Lanka’s WindForce at ‘A+(lka)’; Outlook Stable**

Fitch Ratings has affirmed Sri Lanka-based power generator WindForce PLC’s National Long-Term Rating at ‘A+'(lka). The Outlook is Stable.

WindForce’s rating reflects its growing scale as a prominent renewable power generator in Sri Lanka and several regional markets, its resource diversity and contractual cashflows via long-term power purchase agreements (PPAs). WindForce’s rating is constrained by the credit profile of Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB, A(lka)/Stable), which is a key off-taker accounting for over 80% of WindForce’s EBIT.

Fitch forecasts WindForce’s EBITDA net leverage to rise in the financial year ending March 2027 (FY27) on high debt-funded capex for new generation plants and reduce thereafter as the new plants are commissioned, driving the Stable Outlook. However, inability to deleverage in FY28 in line with our expectations could pressure WindForce’s rating.

**Key Rating Drivers**

**Temporarily High Leverage on Capex:** WindForce expects capex of over LKR40 billion for solar and wind power plants in the next two years with most outflows in FY27. This includes a 100MW solar plant with integrated battery storage, which is Sri Lanka’s largest renewable energy project, under a joint venture with Lakdhanavi Ltd (AA-(lka)/Stable). Fitch estimates WindForce’s generation capacity to rise to over 200MW by FY28 as a result.

EBITDA net leverage will rise to around 6.8x in FY27, before moderating to around 4.6x by FY28 as the plants are commissioned. Execution risks for these projects are low, supported by the company’s record in similar projects, the limited construction complexity of solar and wind projects, the requisite regulatory approvals and offtake agreements in place, with transmission lines constructed or right-of-way established. Additionally, the plants’ long-term PPAs with CEB are in place at preset tariffs, mitigating demand risk.

**Counterparty Constrains Rating:** WindForce’s rating is constrained by the credit profile of CEB, the sole electricity transmitter and distributor in Sri Lanka, despite CEB’s improved financial performance. CEB’s rating depends on support from the Sri Lankan sovereign (Long-Term Local-Currency Issuer Default Rating (IDR): CCC+; Long-Term Foreign-Currency IDR: CCC+).. WindForce derived around 70% of its EBIT from CEB in FY23-FY25, with the share rising to around 80% in FY25 after the commissioning of the Kebitigollewa solar project. We expect WindForce’s cash flow exposure to CEB to increase in FY26-FY29 once new projects are commissioned.

**Risks to Cost-Reflective Tariffs:** Fitch sees risks to CEB’s implementation of cost-reflective tariffs, which could weigh on its balance sheet and pressure settlements to domestic power producers. This is due to the government’s competing priorities of managing inflation, CEB’s financial health, and the state’s own finances. CEB’s EBIT turned negative in 1Q25 due to costs rising faster than approved tariff increases. However, tariff revisions since have improved CEB’s EBIT to breakeven levels in 9M25. WindForce’s average receivable days are steady at around 40 as of 30 September 2025, compared to the peak of around 350 days in FY23.

**Steady EBITDA Margin:** We expect EBITDA margins to improve from around 65% in FY25 to around 70% in FY26-FY28. This reflects operating expenses normalising following increased repairs and maintenance at wind plants, which were deferred from previous years. WindForce’s PPAs offer long-term cash flow visibility, with a weighted-average remaining contract life of over 10 years, but generation volume can be affected by seasonal and climatic patterns. This is mitigated by its diversified portfolio, comprising wind (74MW), solar (55MW) and hydro (15MW) , totaling 145MW, on an alternating current equivalent basis (AC), across 23 power plants excluding associates and joint ventures.

**Peer Analysis**

WindForce is rated one notch below domestic power producer and engineering, procurement and construction contractor Lakdhanavi. The difference is on account of Lakdhanavi’s larger operating scale as a critical base-load power generator in Sri Lanka as well as its higher geographic and business diversification.

Both Lakdhanavi and WindForce have significant exposure to CEB. However, Lakdhanavi also has operations and maintenance (O&M) services, manufactures transformers and switchgears, and offers galvanising services, which provides a degree of diversification. We also believe CEB is likely to prioritise payments to Lakdhanavi even in situations where its own financial profile is stretched, given Lakdhanavi provides O&M services to one of Sri Lanka’s largest power plants, and is investing in a large liquefied natural gas power plant, all of which are critical to Sri Lanka’s power generation and to CEB’s future strategy.

Resus Energy PLC (A-(lka)/Stable), a domestic power producer, is rated two notches below WindForce. Resus also benefits from contractual revenue visibility via its PPAs with CEB. However, Resus’ lower rating reflects its tighter liquidity than WindForce and smaller operating scale with narrower access to domestic banks.

Vidullanka PLC (A+(lka)/Stable) is rated at the same level as WindForce. WindForce has larger operating capacity than Vidullanka and more diversified power generation resources. This is counterbalanced by Vidullanka’s exposure to the state-owned utility of Uganda (B/Stable) and concentration in hydropower generation. Most of Vidullanka’s cash flow stems from overseas, while most of its debt is onshore with Sri Lankan banks, exposing the company to potential repatriation risks. However, Vidullanka’s track record of overseas receipts has been steady.

**Fitch’s Key Rating-Case Assumptions**

Revenue to remain flat in FY26 then increase by over 30% annually in FY27 and FY28 from new projects

EBITDA margin of around 70% in FY26 and FY27;

Receivable days steady at around 40

Capex of around LKR15 billion in FY26 and around LKR30 billion in FY27

Dividend payout of 80% of prior year profit.

**RATING SENSITIVITIES**

**Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Negative Rating Action/Downgrade**  
EBITDA net leverage above 5.0x for a sustained period;  
EBITDA interest coverage below 1.5x for a sustained period.

**Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Positive Rating Action/Upgrade**  
A sustained and substantial reduction in counterparty risk, as reflected in a continued improvement in CEB’s credit profile.

**Liquidity and Debt Structure**

WindForce’s liquidity is subject to timely collection of dues from CEB. The company reported over LKR1.3 billion of readily available cash as of 30 September 2025 and had access to around LKR7 billion in unutilised, albeit uncommitted, credit lines from local banks against LKR1.4 billion of debt maturing in the next 12 months. Maturing debt mainly comprises the current portion of long-term debt obtained to fund the investments in its power plants.

We expect the company to generate negative FCF in the near-to-medium term due to high capex. However, WindForce has adequate access to domestic banks, as most banks are willing to provide longer-tenured facilities for the company’s operating power plants that have more than 10 years remaining under their PPAs.

**Issuer Profile**

WindForce is a leading renewable power producer in Sri Lanka with a total installed power generation capacity of around 145MW (excluding associates and joint ventures) as of 31 March 2025. Most of the installed capacity is in Sri Lanka (132MW), with the rest in Uganda (13MW). The company is listed on the Colombo Stock Exchange.

**REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING**  
The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

Sri Lanka offers grants, low interest loans for businesses hit by Cyclone Ditwah
================================================================================

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:13 am

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:13 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is offering grants of 25,000 to 200,000 rupees for micro and small enterprises affected by Cyclone Ditwah, up to 5 million rupees for commercial building repairs, and 3-5 percent interest loans with 10-year repayment options.

The president’s media division set out the ‘relief package’ as follows:

**New Circular Issued to Support Disaster-Affected Micro, Small and Self-Employed Businesses**

– Financial assistance of Rs. 200,000 for micro, small and self-employed businesses registered with the Ministry of Industry  
– Financial assistance of Rs. 200,000 for micro, small and self-employed businesses registered as businesses at Divisional Secretariat offices  
– Financial assistance of Rs. 50,000 for unregistered home-based businesses operating from permanent structures  
– Rs. 50,000 Compensation Allocated for Unregistered Production Industries and Greenhouses  
– Temporary Pedestrian and Mobile Business establishments to Receive Rs. 25,000 Compensation

A new circular has been issued by the Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development to provide relief to micro, small and self-employed businesses affected by the emergency situation caused by Cyclone Ditwah. The circular has been issued in line with Circular No. 08/2025, which was introduced to restore disrupted livelihoods following the disaster.

The Government programme to empower communities affected by the disaster was introduced through Budget Circular No. 08/2025 dated December 5, 2025. Expanding this relief framework further and ensuring more effective and efficient delivery of assistance, additional circulars No. 08/2025(i) dated December 20, 2025 and No. 08/2025(iii) dated January 22, 2026 have been issued.

The social empowerment programme under the newly issued circular is structured as follows.

Assistance for affected individual, small and micro businesses

A one-time grant to restore businesses damaged by the disaster to a condition suitable for reopening.

LKR 200,000 for individual, small and micro-businesses registered with the Ministry of Industry.

LKR 200,000 for individual, small and micro-businesses registered with the Divisional Secretariat as a business entity.

LKR 50,000 for unregistered home-based businesses operated from a permanent structure.

LKR 50,000 per unit for unregistered production industries, including greenhouses.

LKR 25,000 for temporary business setups, including mobile and street hawking.

A grant will be provided to owners of the commercial buildings affected by the disaster to restore their business premises to operational condition.

A grant of Rs. 500,000/- will be provided to each business building owner who voluntarily opts to receive assistance without a damage assessment.

A grant of up to Rs. 5,000,000/- will be provided to each business building owner who opts to receive assistance after a damage assessment, based on the assessed value of the building.

In addition to the above grants, the following loan facilities have also been provided.

In addition to these grants, the Treasury has introduced a new credit scheme to provide loans for business owners whose enterprises were affected by the disaster, enabling them to restart their operations and meet essential requirements.

Accordingly:

Facilities have been provided for affected businesses to obtain loans ranging from Rs. 250,000 to Rs. 25,000,000 through the banking system at an interest rate of 3%, with a 6-month grace period and repayment over 3 years to restart their operations.

As part of the investment loans for business reconstruction, entrepreneurs whose businesses were damaged can access bank loans of up to Rs. 25 million at an interest rate of 5%, with a 12-month grace period and repayment over 10 years. (Colombo/Jan29/2026)

Sri Lanka’s HNB to offer home loans for Baili Investments’ Silk Rajagiriya
==========================================================================

HNB’s Head of Retail Banking/Senior VP Kanchana Karunagama, exchanges the agreement with Director of Baili Investments, Xueyuan Deng, with representatives of the two organizations.

Thursday January 29, 2026 10:09 am

Thursday January 29, 2026 10:09 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Hatton National Bank is partnering with Baili Investments Lanka (Pvt) Ltd to provide home loans for Silk Rajagiriya, a residential complex being built with recreational facilities.

The development comprises 6 high-rise towers with a shopping complex, cinema, clubhouse, indoor golf, art gallery, rooftop leisure areas, swimming pool, and jogging track.

“Silk Rajagiriya replicates modern living, and we are proud to support the community in accessing this opportunity with confidence,” HNB’s Head of Retail Banking/ Senior Vice President, Kanchana Karunagama, said.

The agreement is valid until 31 December 2026.

Silk Rajagiriya is located at the junction of Buthgamuwa Road and Parliament Road. Construction is currently at the eighth floor with completion projected for September 2028.

Baili Investments is a BOI-registered developer with backing from Hong Kong investors.

“Partnering with HNB ensures home financing is straightforward, strengthens confidence in the real estate sector, and reinforces our commitment to delivering a premium living experience,” Xueyuan Deng, Director of Baili Investments said. (Colombo/Jan29/2026)

Sri Lanka’s Altair issues title deeds under Blackstone management
=================================================================

Thursday January 29, 2026 2:05 pm

Thursday January 29, 2026 2:05 pm

*   [](http://m.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-altair-issues-title-deeds-under-blackstone-management-259346/)
    
*   [](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-altair-issues-title-deeds-under-blackstone-management-259346/)
    
*   [](https://wa.me/?text=https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-altair-issues-title-deeds-under-blackstone-management-259346/)
    

ECONOMYNEXT – Altair Residences, a high rise project in Colombo, has begun issuing title deeds, after being taken over by Blackstone India, a statement said.

The high rise project promoted by Indocean Developers Pvt Ltd (IDPL), was mired in legal disputes before the Blackstone take-over.

Over 100 individual title deeds were executed by apartment owners, providing owners with legal title to their apartments.

The process will be speeded in the future, the statement said.

“Over the past six months, this process at Altair has moved forward in a structured and transparent manner, alongside the formal establishment of owner-led governance,” said Thilan Wijesinghe, Chairman of TWC Holdings, who, together with a team from TWC, represents Blackstone’s interests in Sri Lanka.

Altair’s Management Council has been constituted, and the council appointed Realty Management Services (RMS), a subsidiary of Overseas Realty Ceylon PLC, as the new facility manager of Altair.

“The appointment of experienced facility managers are fundamental building block for long-term value-creation for apartment owners and proper asset stewardship,” Wijesinghe said. (Colombo/Jan29/2026)

Sri Lanka’s hotel bookings dip in December: Chamber chief
=========================================================

By

Ranul Seneviratne

Thursday January 29, 2026 1:13 pm

By Ranul Seneviratne

Thursday January 29, 2026 1:13 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Hotel reservations by tourists in Sri Lanka have dipped in December, after Cyclone Ditwah devastation in November despite hotel damage being minimal, Krishan Balendra, Chairman of the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce said.

“For tourism, I feel that in December, there would have been a 5 percent to 10 percent impact on booking,” Balendra told an economic forum on Wednesday organized by Asia Securities.

In late 2025, Cyclone Ditwah delivered a sharp but localized blow to Sri Lanka’s tourism sector, striking at the onset of the peak travel season.

“In tourism, there were two aspects: the impact on bookings and infrastructure damage,” Balendra said.

“Tourist hotels association collected information from member companies and found the total damage was about 500 million rupees, again, not a material number at all.”

The disaster caused damage to infrastructure in the central highlands, leading to the temporary closure of iconic UNESCO World Heritage sites like Horton Plains and causing an estimated 18-month disruption to the world-famous Kandy-Ella railway line.

While nature-based tourism in the hill country faced the brunt of the storm, major coastal hubs and the Cultural Triangle remained largely operational.

Despite an estimated 4.1 billion dollars in total national damage, the tourism industry has shown resilience; the sector recorded a 9.7 percent growth in arrivals in early 2026 compared to the previous year. (Colombo/Jan29/2026 – Corrected – hotel reservation dip in December, not January)

Sri Lanka’s WindForce ‘A+(lka)’ rating affirmed by Fitch
========================================================

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:57 am

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:57 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Fitch Ratings has affirmed Sri Lanka-based power generator WindForce’s National Long-Term Rating at ‘A+'(lka), with a stable outlook, based on its growing scale as a prominent renewable power generator in the island and several regional markets.

“WindForce’s rating reflects its growing scale as a prominent renewable power generator in Sri Lanka and several regional markets, its resource diversity and contractual cashflows via long-term power purchase agreements (PPAs),” Fitch Ratings said.

However, the rating agency [pointed out](https://www.fitchratings.com/research/corporate-finance/fitch-affirms-sri-lanka-windforce-at-a-lka-outlook-stable-26-01-2026)
 that WindForce’s rating is constrained by the credit profile of CEB, the sole electricity transmitter and distributor in Sri Lanka.

The Fitch statement is reproduced below:

**Fitch Affirms Sri Lanka’s WindForce at ‘A+(lka)’; Outlook Stable**

Fitch Ratings has affirmed Sri Lanka-based power generator WindForce PLC’s National Long-Term Rating at ‘A+'(lka). The Outlook is Stable.

WindForce’s rating reflects its growing scale as a prominent renewable power generator in Sri Lanka and several regional markets, its resource diversity and contractual cashflows via long-term power purchase agreements (PPAs). WindForce’s rating is constrained by the credit profile of Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB, A(lka)/Stable), which is a key off-taker accounting for over 80% of WindForce’s EBIT.

Fitch forecasts WindForce’s EBITDA net leverage to rise in the financial year ending March 2027 (FY27) on high debt-funded capex for new generation plants and reduce thereafter as the new plants are commissioned, driving the Stable Outlook. However, inability to deleverage in FY28 in line with our expectations could pressure WindForce’s rating.

**Key Rating Drivers**

**Temporarily High Leverage on Capex:** WindForce expects capex of over LKR40 billion for solar and wind power plants in the next two years with most outflows in FY27. This includes a 100MW solar plant with integrated battery storage, which is Sri Lanka’s largest renewable energy project, under a joint venture with Lakdhanavi Ltd (AA-(lka)/Stable). Fitch estimates WindForce’s generation capacity to rise to over 200MW by FY28 as a result.

EBITDA net leverage will rise to around 6.8x in FY27, before moderating to around 4.6x by FY28 as the plants are commissioned. Execution risks for these projects are low, supported by the company’s record in similar projects, the limited construction complexity of solar and wind projects, the requisite regulatory approvals and offtake agreements in place, with transmission lines constructed or right-of-way established. Additionally, the plants’ long-term PPAs with CEB are in place at preset tariffs, mitigating demand risk.

**Counterparty Constrains Rating:** WindForce’s rating is constrained by the credit profile of CEB, the sole electricity transmitter and distributor in Sri Lanka, despite CEB’s improved financial performance. CEB’s rating depends on support from the Sri Lankan sovereign (Long-Term Local-Currency Issuer Default Rating (IDR): CCC+; Long-Term Foreign-Currency IDR: CCC+).. WindForce derived around 70% of its EBIT from CEB in FY23-FY25, with the share rising to around 80% in FY25 after the commissioning of the Kebitigollewa solar project. We expect WindForce’s cash flow exposure to CEB to increase in FY26-FY29 once new projects are commissioned.

**Risks to Cost-Reflective Tariffs:** Fitch sees risks to CEB’s implementation of cost-reflective tariffs, which could weigh on its balance sheet and pressure settlements to domestic power producers. This is due to the government’s competing priorities of managing inflation, CEB’s financial health, and the state’s own finances. CEB’s EBIT turned negative in 1Q25 due to costs rising faster than approved tariff increases. However, tariff revisions since have improved CEB’s EBIT to breakeven levels in 9M25. WindForce’s average receivable days are steady at around 40 as of 30 September 2025, compared to the peak of around 350 days in FY23.

**Steady EBITDA Margin:** We expect EBITDA margins to improve from around 65% in FY25 to around 70% in FY26-FY28. This reflects operating expenses normalising following increased repairs and maintenance at wind plants, which were deferred from previous years. WindForce’s PPAs offer long-term cash flow visibility, with a weighted-average remaining contract life of over 10 years, but generation volume can be affected by seasonal and climatic patterns. This is mitigated by its diversified portfolio, comprising wind (74MW), solar (55MW) and hydro (15MW) , totaling 145MW, on an alternating current equivalent basis (AC), across 23 power plants excluding associates and joint ventures.

**Peer Analysis**

WindForce is rated one notch below domestic power producer and engineering, procurement and construction contractor Lakdhanavi. The difference is on account of Lakdhanavi’s larger operating scale as a critical base-load power generator in Sri Lanka as well as its higher geographic and business diversification.

Both Lakdhanavi and WindForce have significant exposure to CEB. However, Lakdhanavi also has operations and maintenance (O&M) services, manufactures transformers and switchgears, and offers galvanising services, which provides a degree of diversification. We also believe CEB is likely to prioritise payments to Lakdhanavi even in situations where its own financial profile is stretched, given Lakdhanavi provides O&M services to one of Sri Lanka’s largest power plants, and is investing in a large liquefied natural gas power plant, all of which are critical to Sri Lanka’s power generation and to CEB’s future strategy.

Resus Energy PLC (A-(lka)/Stable), a domestic power producer, is rated two notches below WindForce. Resus also benefits from contractual revenue visibility via its PPAs with CEB. However, Resus’ lower rating reflects its tighter liquidity than WindForce and smaller operating scale with narrower access to domestic banks.

Vidullanka PLC (A+(lka)/Stable) is rated at the same level as WindForce. WindForce has larger operating capacity than Vidullanka and more diversified power generation resources. This is counterbalanced by Vidullanka’s exposure to the state-owned utility of Uganda (B/Stable) and concentration in hydropower generation. Most of Vidullanka’s cash flow stems from overseas, while most of its debt is onshore with Sri Lankan banks, exposing the company to potential repatriation risks. However, Vidullanka’s track record of overseas receipts has been steady.

**Fitch’s Key Rating-Case Assumptions**

Revenue to remain flat in FY26 then increase by over 30% annually in FY27 and FY28 from new projects

EBITDA margin of around 70% in FY26 and FY27;

Receivable days steady at around 40

Capex of around LKR15 billion in FY26 and around LKR30 billion in FY27

Dividend payout of 80% of prior year profit.

**RATING SENSITIVITIES**

**Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Negative Rating Action/Downgrade**  
EBITDA net leverage above 5.0x for a sustained period;  
EBITDA interest coverage below 1.5x for a sustained period.

**Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Positive Rating Action/Upgrade**  
A sustained and substantial reduction in counterparty risk, as reflected in a continued improvement in CEB’s credit profile.

**Liquidity and Debt Structure**

WindForce’s liquidity is subject to timely collection of dues from CEB. The company reported over LKR1.3 billion of readily available cash as of 30 September 2025 and had access to around LKR7 billion in unutilised, albeit uncommitted, credit lines from local banks against LKR1.4 billion of debt maturing in the next 12 months. Maturing debt mainly comprises the current portion of long-term debt obtained to fund the investments in its power plants.

We expect the company to generate negative FCF in the near-to-medium term due to high capex. However, WindForce has adequate access to domestic banks, as most banks are willing to provide longer-tenured facilities for the company’s operating power plants that have more than 10 years remaining under their PPAs.

**Issuer Profile**

WindForce is a leading renewable power producer in Sri Lanka with a total installed power generation capacity of around 145MW (excluding associates and joint ventures) as of 31 March 2025. Most of the installed capacity is in Sri Lanka (132MW), with the rest in Uganda (13MW). The company is listed on the Colombo Stock Exchange.

**REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING**  
The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

Sri Lanka offers grants, low interest loans for businesses hit by Cyclone Ditwah
================================================================================

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:13 am

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:13 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is offering grants of 25,000 to 200,000 rupees for micro and small enterprises affected by Cyclone Ditwah, up to 5 million rupees for commercial building repairs, and 3-5 percent interest loans with 10-year repayment options.

The president’s media division set out the ‘relief package’ as follows:

**New Circular Issued to Support Disaster-Affected Micro, Small and Self-Employed Businesses**

– Financial assistance of Rs. 200,000 for micro, small and self-employed businesses registered with the Ministry of Industry  
– Financial assistance of Rs. 200,000 for micro, small and self-employed businesses registered as businesses at Divisional Secretariat offices  
– Financial assistance of Rs. 50,000 for unregistered home-based businesses operating from permanent structures  
– Rs. 50,000 Compensation Allocated for Unregistered Production Industries and Greenhouses  
– Temporary Pedestrian and Mobile Business establishments to Receive Rs. 25,000 Compensation

A new circular has been issued by the Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development to provide relief to micro, small and self-employed businesses affected by the emergency situation caused by Cyclone Ditwah. The circular has been issued in line with Circular No. 08/2025, which was introduced to restore disrupted livelihoods following the disaster.

The Government programme to empower communities affected by the disaster was introduced through Budget Circular No. 08/2025 dated December 5, 2025. Expanding this relief framework further and ensuring more effective and efficient delivery of assistance, additional circulars No. 08/2025(i) dated December 20, 2025 and No. 08/2025(iii) dated January 22, 2026 have been issued.

The social empowerment programme under the newly issued circular is structured as follows.

Assistance for affected individual, small and micro businesses

A one-time grant to restore businesses damaged by the disaster to a condition suitable for reopening.

LKR 200,000 for individual, small and micro-businesses registered with the Ministry of Industry.

LKR 200,000 for individual, small and micro-businesses registered with the Divisional Secretariat as a business entity.

LKR 50,000 for unregistered home-based businesses operated from a permanent structure.

LKR 50,000 per unit for unregistered production industries, including greenhouses.

LKR 25,000 for temporary business setups, including mobile and street hawking.

A grant will be provided to owners of the commercial buildings affected by the disaster to restore their business premises to operational condition.

A grant of Rs. 500,000/- will be provided to each business building owner who voluntarily opts to receive assistance without a damage assessment.

A grant of up to Rs. 5,000,000/- will be provided to each business building owner who opts to receive assistance after a damage assessment, based on the assessed value of the building.

In addition to the above grants, the following loan facilities have also been provided.

In addition to these grants, the Treasury has introduced a new credit scheme to provide loans for business owners whose enterprises were affected by the disaster, enabling them to restart their operations and meet essential requirements.

Accordingly:

Facilities have been provided for affected businesses to obtain loans ranging from Rs. 250,000 to Rs. 25,000,000 through the banking system at an interest rate of 3%, with a 6-month grace period and repayment over 3 years to restart their operations.

As part of the investment loans for business reconstruction, entrepreneurs whose businesses were damaged can access bank loans of up to Rs. 25 million at an interest rate of 5%, with a 12-month grace period and repayment over 10 years. (Colombo/Jan29/2026)

The development comprises 6 high-rise towers with a shopping complex, cinema, clubhouse, indoor golf, art gallery, rooftop leisure areas, swimming pool, and jogging track.

Sri Lanka John Keells Holding’s December net jumps 128-pct helped by BYD, casino
================================================================================

Wednesday January 28, 2026 7:18 pm

Wednesday January 28, 2026 7:18 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Profits at Sri Lanka’s John Keells Holdings rose 128 percent to 6.5 billion rupees in the December 2025 quarter with strong revenues from its vehicle sales and casino operations. 

The group reported earnings of 0.37 rupee per share for the quarter. In the nine months to December the country’s top market heavyweight reported earnings of 0.41 cents per share, on total profits of 7.3 billion rupees, which was up 119 percent.

JKH group revenues rose 54 percent to 125 billion rupees in the September quarter, cost of sales rose 52 percent to 98.3 billion rupees and gross profit rose 62 percent to 26 billion rupees.

Revenue and earnings before interest tax and depreciation was primarily driven by electric and hybrid vehicle sales, financial services and City of Dreams Sri Lanka which recorded a positive EBITDA of 1.4 billion rupees, against a negative 1.6 billion a year ago, Chairman Krishan Balendra told shareholders in the earnings report.

This positive EBITDA, includes fair value gains made on investment property, as opposed to the previous year’s negative EBITDA, which did not include fair value gains.

The casino has also had steady gains, with JKH recognising fixed rental incomes from it for the full quarter. Variable rental incomes will be considered once casino revenue reaches a certain target, the company said.

Following a customs dispute over the motor capacity of imported BYDs, JKH halted the delivery of the vehicles and filed a lawsuit against Sri Lanka Customs.

These vehicles have subsequently been released, save for ones held back for testing. While awaiting a conclusion on this matter, JKH has ramped up its focus on hybrid vehicles. Over 3900 vehicles await their delivery over the preceding months, the conglomerate said.

“JKCG (John Keells CG Auto) has fully cooperated with the authorities and continues to advocate carrying out independent testing at an internationally accredited motor laboratory,” Balendra said.  

“We remain committed and resolute in our efforts to arrive at an expeditious permanent solution to this matter, so as to ensure our prospective customers have the benefit of a wider choice in deciding their purchase of BYDs expansive range of vehicles.”

“JKCG has concurrently ramped up its focus on the hybrid segment offered by BYD and has also seen strong interest for these models.”

The Colombo West International Terminal also showed steady month-on-month growth, recording positive profit after tax, surpassing expectations. (Colombo/January 28th/2026)

Sri Lanka’s hotel bookings dip in December: Chamber chief
=========================================================

By

Ranul Seneviratne

Thursday January 29, 2026 1:13 pm

By Ranul Seneviratne

Thursday January 29, 2026 1:13 pm

*   [](http://m.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-hotel-bookings-dip-in-december-chamber-chief-259325/)
    
*   [](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-hotel-bookings-dip-in-december-chamber-chief-259325/)
    
*   [](https://wa.me/?text=https://economynext.com/sri-lankas-hotel-bookings-dip-in-december-chamber-chief-259325/)
    

ECONOMYNEXT – Hotel reservations by tourists in Sri Lanka have dipped in December, after Cyclone Ditwah devastation in November despite hotel damage being minimal, Krishan Balendra, Chairman of the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce said.

“For tourism, I feel that in December, there would have been a 5 percent to 10 percent impact on booking,” Balendra told an economic forum on Wednesday organized by Asia Securities.

In late 2025, Cyclone Ditwah delivered a sharp but localized blow to Sri Lanka’s tourism sector, striking at the onset of the peak travel season.

“In tourism, there were two aspects: the impact on bookings and infrastructure damage,” Balendra said.

“Tourist hotels association collected information from member companies and found the total damage was about 500 million rupees, again, not a material number at all.”

The disaster caused damage to infrastructure in the central highlands, leading to the temporary closure of iconic UNESCO World Heritage sites like Horton Plains and causing an estimated 18-month disruption to the world-famous Kandy-Ella railway line.

While nature-based tourism in the hill country faced the brunt of the storm, major coastal hubs and the Cultural Triangle remained largely operational.

Despite an estimated 4.1 billion dollars in total national damage, the tourism industry has shown resilience; the sector recorded a 9.7 percent growth in arrivals in early 2026 compared to the previous year. (Colombo/Jan29/2026 – Corrected – hotel reservation dip in December, not January)

Sri Lanka’s WindForce ‘A+(lka)’ rating affirmed by Fitch
========================================================

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:57 am

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:57 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Fitch Ratings has affirmed Sri Lanka-based power generator WindForce’s National Long-Term Rating at ‘A+'(lka), with a stable outlook, based on its growing scale as a prominent renewable power generator in the island and several regional markets.

“WindForce’s rating reflects its growing scale as a prominent renewable power generator in Sri Lanka and several regional markets, its resource diversity and contractual cashflows via long-term power purchase agreements (PPAs),” Fitch Ratings said.

However, the rating agency [pointed out](https://www.fitchratings.com/research/corporate-finance/fitch-affirms-sri-lanka-windforce-at-a-lka-outlook-stable-26-01-2026)
 that WindForce’s rating is constrained by the credit profile of CEB, the sole electricity transmitter and distributor in Sri Lanka.

The Fitch statement is reproduced below:

**Fitch Affirms Sri Lanka’s WindForce at ‘A+(lka)’; Outlook Stable**

Fitch Ratings has affirmed Sri Lanka-based power generator WindForce PLC’s National Long-Term Rating at ‘A+'(lka). The Outlook is Stable.

WindForce’s rating reflects its growing scale as a prominent renewable power generator in Sri Lanka and several regional markets, its resource diversity and contractual cashflows via long-term power purchase agreements (PPAs). WindForce’s rating is constrained by the credit profile of Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB, A(lka)/Stable), which is a key off-taker accounting for over 80% of WindForce’s EBIT.

Fitch forecasts WindForce’s EBITDA net leverage to rise in the financial year ending March 2027 (FY27) on high debt-funded capex for new generation plants and reduce thereafter as the new plants are commissioned, driving the Stable Outlook. However, inability to deleverage in FY28 in line with our expectations could pressure WindForce’s rating.

**Key Rating Drivers**

**Temporarily High Leverage on Capex:** WindForce expects capex of over LKR40 billion for solar and wind power plants in the next two years with most outflows in FY27. This includes a 100MW solar plant with integrated battery storage, which is Sri Lanka’s largest renewable energy project, under a joint venture with Lakdhanavi Ltd (AA-(lka)/Stable). Fitch estimates WindForce’s generation capacity to rise to over 200MW by FY28 as a result.

EBITDA net leverage will rise to around 6.8x in FY27, before moderating to around 4.6x by FY28 as the plants are commissioned. Execution risks for these projects are low, supported by the company’s record in similar projects, the limited construction complexity of solar and wind projects, the requisite regulatory approvals and offtake agreements in place, with transmission lines constructed or right-of-way established. Additionally, the plants’ long-term PPAs with CEB are in place at preset tariffs, mitigating demand risk.

**Counterparty Constrains Rating:** WindForce’s rating is constrained by the credit profile of CEB, the sole electricity transmitter and distributor in Sri Lanka, despite CEB’s improved financial performance. CEB’s rating depends on support from the Sri Lankan sovereign (Long-Term Local-Currency Issuer Default Rating (IDR): CCC+; Long-Term Foreign-Currency IDR: CCC+).. WindForce derived around 70% of its EBIT from CEB in FY23-FY25, with the share rising to around 80% in FY25 after the commissioning of the Kebitigollewa solar project. We expect WindForce’s cash flow exposure to CEB to increase in FY26-FY29 once new projects are commissioned.

**Risks to Cost-Reflective Tariffs:** Fitch sees risks to CEB’s implementation of cost-reflective tariffs, which could weigh on its balance sheet and pressure settlements to domestic power producers. This is due to the government’s competing priorities of managing inflation, CEB’s financial health, and the state’s own finances. CEB’s EBIT turned negative in 1Q25 due to costs rising faster than approved tariff increases. However, tariff revisions since have improved CEB’s EBIT to breakeven levels in 9M25. WindForce’s average receivable days are steady at around 40 as of 30 September 2025, compared to the peak of around 350 days in FY23.

**Steady EBITDA Margin:** We expect EBITDA margins to improve from around 65% in FY25 to around 70% in FY26-FY28. This reflects operating expenses normalising following increased repairs and maintenance at wind plants, which were deferred from previous years. WindForce’s PPAs offer long-term cash flow visibility, with a weighted-average remaining contract life of over 10 years, but generation volume can be affected by seasonal and climatic patterns. This is mitigated by its diversified portfolio, comprising wind (74MW), solar (55MW) and hydro (15MW) , totaling 145MW, on an alternating current equivalent basis (AC), across 23 power plants excluding associates and joint ventures.

**Peer Analysis**

WindForce is rated one notch below domestic power producer and engineering, procurement and construction contractor Lakdhanavi. The difference is on account of Lakdhanavi’s larger operating scale as a critical base-load power generator in Sri Lanka as well as its higher geographic and business diversification.

Both Lakdhanavi and WindForce have significant exposure to CEB. However, Lakdhanavi also has operations and maintenance (O&M) services, manufactures transformers and switchgears, and offers galvanising services, which provides a degree of diversification. We also believe CEB is likely to prioritise payments to Lakdhanavi even in situations where its own financial profile is stretched, given Lakdhanavi provides O&M services to one of Sri Lanka’s largest power plants, and is investing in a large liquefied natural gas power plant, all of which are critical to Sri Lanka’s power generation and to CEB’s future strategy.

Resus Energy PLC (A-(lka)/Stable), a domestic power producer, is rated two notches below WindForce. Resus also benefits from contractual revenue visibility via its PPAs with CEB. However, Resus’ lower rating reflects its tighter liquidity than WindForce and smaller operating scale with narrower access to domestic banks.

Vidullanka PLC (A+(lka)/Stable) is rated at the same level as WindForce. WindForce has larger operating capacity than Vidullanka and more diversified power generation resources. This is counterbalanced by Vidullanka’s exposure to the state-owned utility of Uganda (B/Stable) and concentration in hydropower generation. Most of Vidullanka’s cash flow stems from overseas, while most of its debt is onshore with Sri Lankan banks, exposing the company to potential repatriation risks. However, Vidullanka’s track record of overseas receipts has been steady.

**Fitch’s Key Rating-Case Assumptions**

Revenue to remain flat in FY26 then increase by over 30% annually in FY27 and FY28 from new projects

EBITDA margin of around 70% in FY26 and FY27;

Receivable days steady at around 40

Capex of around LKR15 billion in FY26 and around LKR30 billion in FY27

Dividend payout of 80% of prior year profit.

**RATING SENSITIVITIES**

**Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Negative Rating Action/Downgrade**  
EBITDA net leverage above 5.0x for a sustained period;  
EBITDA interest coverage below 1.5x for a sustained period.

**Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Positive Rating Action/Upgrade**  
A sustained and substantial reduction in counterparty risk, as reflected in a continued improvement in CEB’s credit profile.

**Liquidity and Debt Structure**

WindForce’s liquidity is subject to timely collection of dues from CEB. The company reported over LKR1.3 billion of readily available cash as of 30 September 2025 and had access to around LKR7 billion in unutilised, albeit uncommitted, credit lines from local banks against LKR1.4 billion of debt maturing in the next 12 months. Maturing debt mainly comprises the current portion of long-term debt obtained to fund the investments in its power plants.

We expect the company to generate negative FCF in the near-to-medium term due to high capex. However, WindForce has adequate access to domestic banks, as most banks are willing to provide longer-tenured facilities for the company’s operating power plants that have more than 10 years remaining under their PPAs.

**Issuer Profile**

WindForce is a leading renewable power producer in Sri Lanka with a total installed power generation capacity of around 145MW (excluding associates and joint ventures) as of 31 March 2025. Most of the installed capacity is in Sri Lanka (132MW), with the rest in Uganda (13MW). The company is listed on the Colombo Stock Exchange.

**REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING**  
The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

Sri Lanka offers grants, low interest loans for businesses hit by Cyclone Ditwah
================================================================================

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:13 am

Thursday January 29, 2026 11:13 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is offering grants of 25,000 to 200,000 rupees for micro and small enterprises affected by Cyclone Ditwah, up to 5 million rupees for commercial building repairs, and 3-5 percent interest loans with 10-year repayment options.

The president’s media division set out the ‘relief package’ as follows:

**New Circular Issued to Support Disaster-Affected Micro, Small and Self-Employed Businesses**

– Financial assistance of Rs. 200,000 for micro, small and self-employed businesses registered with the Ministry of Industry  
– Financial assistance of Rs. 200,000 for micro, small and self-employed businesses registered as businesses at Divisional Secretariat offices  
– Financial assistance of Rs. 50,000 for unregistered home-based businesses operating from permanent structures  
– Rs. 50,000 Compensation Allocated for Unregistered Production Industries and Greenhouses  
– Temporary Pedestrian and Mobile Business establishments to Receive Rs. 25,000 Compensation

A new circular has been issued by the Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development to provide relief to micro, small and self-employed businesses affected by the emergency situation caused by Cyclone Ditwah. The circular has been issued in line with Circular No. 08/2025, which was introduced to restore disrupted livelihoods following the disaster.

The Government programme to empower communities affected by the disaster was introduced through Budget Circular No. 08/2025 dated December 5, 2025. Expanding this relief framework further and ensuring more effective and efficient delivery of assistance, additional circulars No. 08/2025(i) dated December 20, 2025 and No. 08/2025(iii) dated January 22, 2026 have been issued.

The social empowerment programme under the newly issued circular is structured as follows.

Assistance for affected individual, small and micro businesses

A one-time grant to restore businesses damaged by the disaster to a condition suitable for reopening.

LKR 200,000 for individual, small and micro-businesses registered with the Ministry of Industry.

LKR 200,000 for individual, small and micro-businesses registered with the Divisional Secretariat as a business entity.

LKR 50,000 for unregistered home-based businesses operated from a permanent structure.

LKR 50,000 per unit for unregistered production industries, including greenhouses.

LKR 25,000 for temporary business setups, including mobile and street hawking.

A grant will be provided to owners of the commercial buildings affected by the disaster to restore their business premises to operational condition.

A grant of Rs. 500,000/- will be provided to each business building owner who voluntarily opts to receive assistance without a damage assessment.

A grant of up to Rs. 5,000,000/- will be provided to each business building owner who opts to receive assistance after a damage assessment, based on the assessed value of the building.

In addition to the above grants, the following loan facilities have also been provided.

In addition to these grants, the Treasury has introduced a new credit scheme to provide loans for business owners whose enterprises were affected by the disaster, enabling them to restart their operations and meet essential requirements.

Accordingly:

Facilities have been provided for affected businesses to obtain loans ranging from Rs. 250,000 to Rs. 25,000,000 through the banking system at an interest rate of 3%, with a 6-month grace period and repayment over 3 years to restart their operations.

As part of the investment loans for business reconstruction, entrepreneurs whose businesses were damaged can access bank loans of up to Rs. 25 million at an interest rate of 5%, with a 12-month grace period and repayment over 10 years. (Colombo/Jan29/2026)

Sri Lanka’s HNB to offer home loans for Baili Investments’ Silk Rajagiriya
==========================================================================

HNB’s Head of Retail Banking/Senior VP Kanchana Karunagama, exchanges the agreement with Director of Baili Investments, Xueyuan Deng, with representatives of the two organizations.

Thursday January 29, 2026 10:09 am

Thursday January 29, 2026 10:09 am

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Hatton National Bank is partnering with Baili Investments Lanka (Pvt) Ltd to provide home loans for Silk Rajagiriya, a residential complex being built with recreational facilities.

The development comprises 6 high-rise towers with a shopping complex, cinema, clubhouse, indoor golf, art gallery, rooftop leisure areas, swimming pool, and jogging track.

“Silk Rajagiriya replicates modern living, and we are proud to support the community in accessing this opportunity with confidence,” HNB’s Head of Retail Banking/ Senior Vice President, Kanchana Karunagama, said.

The agreement is valid until 31 December 2026.

Silk Rajagiriya is located at the junction of Buthgamuwa Road and Parliament Road. Construction is currently at the eighth floor with completion projected for September 2028.

Baili Investments is a BOI-registered developer with backing from Hong Kong investors.

“Partnering with HNB ensures home financing is straightforward, strengthens confidence in the real estate sector, and reinforces our commitment to delivering a premium living experience,” Xueyuan Deng, Director of Baili Investments said. (Colombo/Jan29/2026)

Sri Lanka John Keells Holding’s December net jumps 128-pct helped by BYD, casino
================================================================================

Wednesday January 28, 2026 7:18 pm

Wednesday January 28, 2026 7:18 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Profits at Sri Lanka’s John Keells Holdings rose 128 percent to 6.5 billion rupees in the December 2025 quarter with strong revenues from its vehicle sales and casino operations. 

The group reported earnings of 0.37 rupee per share for the quarter. In the nine months to December the country’s top market heavyweight reported earnings of 0.41 cents per share, on total profits of 7.3 billion rupees, which was up 119 percent.

JKH group revenues rose 54 percent to 125 billion rupees in the September quarter, cost of sales rose 52 percent to 98.3 billion rupees and gross profit rose 62 percent to 26 billion rupees.

Revenue and earnings before interest tax and depreciation was primarily driven by electric and hybrid vehicle sales, financial services and City of Dreams Sri Lanka which recorded a positive EBITDA of 1.4 billion rupees, against a negative 1.6 billion a year ago, Chairman Krishan Balendra told shareholders in the earnings report.

This positive EBITDA, includes fair value gains made on investment property, as opposed to the previous year’s negative EBITDA, which did not include fair value gains.

The casino has also had steady gains, with JKH recognising fixed rental incomes from it for the full quarter. Variable rental incomes will be considered once casino revenue reaches a certain target, the company said.

Following a customs dispute over the motor capacity of imported BYDs, JKH halted the delivery of the vehicles and filed a lawsuit against Sri Lanka Customs.

These vehicles have subsequently been released, save for ones held back for testing. While awaiting a conclusion on this matter, JKH has ramped up its focus on hybrid vehicles. Over 3900 vehicles await their delivery over the preceding months, the conglomerate said.

“JKCG (John Keells CG Auto) has fully cooperated with the authorities and continues to advocate carrying out independent testing at an internationally accredited motor laboratory,” Balendra said.  

“We remain committed and resolute in our efforts to arrive at an expeditious permanent solution to this matter, so as to ensure our prospective customers have the benefit of a wider choice in deciding their purchase of BYDs expansive range of vehicles.”

“JKCG has concurrently ramped up its focus on the hybrid segment offered by BYD and has also seen strong interest for these models.”

The Colombo West International Terminal also showed steady month-on-month growth, recording positive profit after tax, surpassing expectations. (Colombo/January 28th/2026)

Sri Lanka launches first airport e-gates to modernize border security, health resilience
========================================================================================

Wednesday January 28, 2026 6:35 pm

Wednesday January 28, 2026 6:35 pm

ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka launched its first Automated Border Control (ABC) e-gates at Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) on Wednesday aiming for a modern aviation hub, a joint statement said.

The initiative, a partnership between the Ministry of Ports and Civil Aviation, the Embassy of Japan, and the International Organization for Migration (IOM), aims to streamline passenger travel while strengthening the nation’s defenses against public health risks.

The project, valued at USD 8.4 million, was funded by the Government of Japan and implemented by the IOM. It introduces cutting-edge technology including biometric access controls and advanced screening systems designed to enhance both security and efficiency at the country’s primary entryway.

“Sri Lanka remains committed to advancing its aviation and port sectors through modernization, guided by global standards in safety, health, and sustainability,” Anura Karunathilaka, Minister of Ports and Civil Aviation said, adding that these efforts reinforce the nation’s role as a “secure and efficient gateway”.

The launch comes at a critical time as Sri Lanka recovers from the devastation of Cyclone Ditwah.

Ambassador of Japan H.E. Akio Isomata noted that the recent disaster underscored the need for resilient borders.

“The recent severe cyclone has underscored the importance of preparedness and resilience at borders, not only in response to pandemics, but also in the context of disasters,” Isomata stated.

He further reaffirmed Japan’s long-term commitment to Sri Lanka’s sustainable development, including ongoing yen-loan assistance for a new terminal at BIA.

The IOM, which led the technical implementation, highlighted the broader regional impact and said it was proud to lead the technical innovation behind this milestone.

Passengers are expected to experience faster immigration clearance through the new e-gates, significantly reducing waiting times. (Colombo/January 28/2026)
